editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

div.p: As it hath been lately acted by the children of Paul's.
London printed, and are to be sold by John Hodgets in Paul's churchyard. 1607.

div.head: The prologue.
div.p:
Gentlemen, inductions are out of date, and a prologue in verse is as stale, as a black velvet cloak, and a bay garland: therefore you shall have it plain prose thus: if there be any amongst you, that come to hear lascivious scenes, let them depart: for I do pronounce this, to the utter discomfort of all two penny gallery men, you shall have no bawdry in it: or if there be any lurking amongst you in corners, with table books, who have some hope to find fit matter to feed his â€” malice on, let them clasp them up, and slink away, or stay and be converted. For he that made this play, means to please auditors so, as he may be an auditor himself hereafter, and not purchase them with the dear loss of his ears: I dare not call it comedy, or tragedy; 'tis perfectly neither: a play it is, which was meant to make you laugh, how it will please you, is not written in my part: for though you should like it today, perhaps yourselves know not how you should digest it tomorrow: some things in it you may meet with, which are out of the common road: a Duke there is, and the scene lies in Italy, as those two
things lightly we never miss. But you shall not find in it the ordinary and overworn trade of jesting at lords and courtiers, and citizens, without taxation of any particular or new vice by them found out, but at the persons of them: such, he that made this, thinks vile; and for his own part vows, that he did never think, but that a lord born might be a wise man, and a courtier an honest man.

div.stage: Enter Duke of Millaine, Arrigo, Lucio, and two courtiers.
div.p: 'Tis now the sweetest time for sleep, the night is scarce spent; Arrigo, what's o'clock ?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Past four.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is it so much, and yet the morn not up?
See yonder where the shamefaced maiden comes
Into our sight, how gently doth she slide,
Hiding her chaste cheeks, like a modest bride,
With a red veil of blushes; as is she,
Even such all modest virtuous women be.
Why thinks your lordship I am up so soon?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: About some weighty state plot.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: And what thinks your knighthood of it?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: I do think, to cure some strange corruptions in the common wealth.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You're well conceited of yourselves, to think
I choose you out to bear me company
In such affairs and business of state:
But am not I a pattern for all princes,
That break my soft sleep for my subjects' good?
Am I not careful? very provident?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Your grace is careful.

sp.speaker: Arri.
sp.p: Very provident.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Nay knew you how my serious working plots,
Concern the whole estates of all my subjects,
I and their lives; then Lucio thou wouldst swear,
I were a loving prince.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: I think your grace intends to walk the public streets disguised, to see the streets disorders.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: It is not so.

sp.speaker: Arrig.
sp.p: You secretly will cross some other states, that do conspire against you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Weightier far:
You are my friends, and you shall have the cause;
I break my sleeps thus soon to see a wench.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: You're wondrous careful for your subjects' good.

sp.speaker: Arrig.
sp.p: You are a very loving prince in deed.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This care I take for them, when their dull eyes,
Are closed with heavy slumbers.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Then you rise to see your wenches?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: What Milan beauty hath the power, to charm her sovereign's eyes, and break his sleeps?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sister to count Vaelore: she's a maid
Would make a prince, forget his throne and state,
And lowly kneel to her: the general fate
Of all mortality, is hers to give;
As she disposeth, so we die and live.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My lord, the day grows clear, the court will rise.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We stay too long, is the the Umbrano's head as we commanded, sent to the sad Gondarino, our general?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: 'Tis sent.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: But stay, where shines that light?

sp.speaker: Arrig.
sp.p: 'Tis in the chamber of Lazarello.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lazarello? what is he?

sp.speaker: Arrig.
sp.p: A courtier my lord, and one that I wonder your grace knows not: for he hath followed your court, and your last predecessors, from place to place, any time this seven year, as faithfully as your spits and your dripping-pans have done, and almost as greasily.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: O we know him as we have heard: he keeps a calendar of all the famous dishes of meat, that have been in the court, ever since our great grandfathers time; and when he can thrust in at no table, he makes his meat of that.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.p: The very same my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A courtier call'st thou him?
Believe me Lucio, there be many such
About our court, respected, as they think,
Even by ourself; with thee I will be plain:
sp.p: We princes do use, to prefer many for nothing, and to take particular and free knowledge, almost in the nature of acquaintance of many; whom we do use only for our pleasures, and do give largely to numbers; more out of policy, to be thought liberal, and by that means to make the people strive to deserve our love; then to reward any particular desert of theirs, to whom we give: and do suffer ourselves to here flatterers, more for recreation
sp.l: Then for love of it, though we seldom hate it:
And yet we know all these, and when we please,
Can touch the wheel, and turn their names about.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I wonder they that know their states so well, should fancy such base slaves.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou wonder'st Lucio,
Dost not thou think, if thou wert Duke of Milan,
Thou shouldst be flattered?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.p: I know my lord, I would not.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why so I thought till I was Duke, I thought I should have left me no more flatterers, than there are now plain-dealers; and yet for all this my resolution, I am most palpably flattered: the poor man may loathe covetousness and flattery; but fortune will alter the mind when the wind turns: there may be well a little conflict, but it will drive the billows before it.
sp.l: Arrigo it grows late, for see fair Thetis hath undone the bars
To Phoebus' team; and his unrivalled light,
Hath chased the morning's modest blush away:
Now must we to our love, bright Paphian Queen;
Thou Cytherean goddess, that delights
In stirring glances, and art still thyself,
More toying than thy team of sparrows be;
Thou laughing Errecina oh inspire
her heart with love, or lessen my desire.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Go run, search, pry in every nook and angle of the kitchens, larders, and pasteries, know what meat's boiled, baked, roast, stewed, fried, or soused, at this dinner to be served directly, or indirectly, to every several table in the court, be gone.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I run, but not so fast, as your mouth will do upon the stroke of eleven.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p:
What an excellent thing did God bestow upon man, when he did give him a good stomach? what unbounded graces there are poured upon them, that have the continual command of the very best of these blessings? 'tis an excellent thing to be a prince, he is served with such admirable variety of fare; such innumerable choice of delicates, his tables are full fraught with most nourishing food, and his cupboards heavy laden with rich wines; his court is still filled with most pleasing varieties: in the summer, his palace is full of green geese; and in winter, it swarmeth woodcocks,
Oh thou goddess of plenty
Fill me this day with some rare delicates,
And I will every year most constantly,
As this day celebrate a sumptuous feast,
If thou wilt send me victuals in thine honour;
And to it shall be bidden for thy sake,
Even all the valiant stomachs in the court:
All short-cloaked knights, and all cross-gartered gentlemen;
All pump and pantofle, foot-cloth riders;
With all the swarming generation
Of long stocks, short pained hose, and huge stuffed doublets:
All these shall eat, and which is more than yet
Hath ere been seen, they shall be satisfied.
I wonder my ambassador returns not!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here I am master.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: And welcome:
Never did that sweet virgin in her smock,
Fair cheeked Andromeda, when to the rock
Her ivory limbs were chained, and straight before
A huge sea monster, tumbling to the shore,
To have devoured her, with more longing sight
Expect the coming of some hardy knight,
That might have quelled his pride, and set her free,
Than I with longing sight have looked for thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Your Perseus is come master, that will destroy him,
The very comfort of whole presence shuts
The monster hunger from your yelping guts

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Brief boy, brief, discourse the service of each several table compendiously.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here's a bill of all sir.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: Give it me. A bill of all the several services this day appointed for every table in the court:
Ay, this is it on which my hopes rely;
Within this paper all my joys are closed:
Boy open it, and read it with reverence.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: For the captain of the guards table, three chines of beef, and two jolls of sturgeon.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: A portly service, but gross, gross, proceed to the Duke's own table, dear boy to the Duke's own table.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: For the Duke's own table, the head of an Umbrana

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Is't possible! can heaven be so propitious to the Duke?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, I'll assure you sir, 'tis possible, heaven is so propitious to him.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: Why then he is the richest prince alive:
He were the wealthiest monarch in all Europe,
Had he no other territories, dominions, provinces, seats,
Nor palaces, but only that Umbrana's head.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Tis very fresh and sweet sir, the fish was taken but this night, and the head as a rare novelty appointed by special commandment for the Duke's own table, this dinner.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: If poor unworthy I may come to eat of this most sacred dish, I here do vow (If that blind housewife fortune will bestow but means on me) to keep a sumptuous house, a board groaning under the heavy burden of the beasts that cheweth the cud, and the foul that cutteth the air: I shall not like the table of a country justice, besprinkled over with all manner of cheap salads, sliced beef, giblets, and pettitoes, to fill up room, nor should there stand any great, cumbersome, uncut up pies at the nether end filled with moss and stones, partly to make a show with, and partly to keep the lower mess from eating, nor shall my meat come in sneaking like the city-service, one dish a quarter of an hour after one another gone, as if they had appointed to meet there, and had mistook the hour, nor should it like the new court service come in, in haste, as if it fain would be gone again, all courses at once, like a hunting breakfast, but I would have my several courses, and my dishes well filled, my first course should be brought in after the ancient manner, by a score of old blear-eyed serving-men, in long blue coats, (Marry they shall buy silk, facing, and buttons themselves) but that's by the way.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Master the time calls on, will you be walking.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Follow boy, follow, my guts were half an hour since in the privy kitchen.

div.head: Scaena tertii.
div.stage: Enter count and his sister Oriana.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Faith brother I must needs go yonder.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And i'faith sister what will you do yonder.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: I know the lady Honoria will be glad to see me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Glad to see you, faith the lady Honoria cares for you as she doth for all other young ladies, she's glad to
see you, and will show you the privy garden, and tell you how many gowns the Duchess had: marry if you have ever an old uncle, that would be a lord, or ever a kinsman that hath done a murder, or committed a robbery, and will give good store of money to procure his pardon, than the lady Honoria will be glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Ay, but they say one shall see fine fights at the court.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I'll tell you what you shall see, you shall see many faces of man's making, for you shall find very few as God left them: and you shall see many legs too; amongst the rest you shall behold one pair, the feet of which, were in times passed sockless, but are now through the change of time (That alters all things) very strangely become the legs of a knight and a courtier: another pair you shall see, that were heir apparent legs to a glover, these legs hope shortly to be honourable; when they pass by they will bow, and the mouth to these legs, will seem to offer you some courtship; it will swear, but it will lie, hear it not.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Why, and are not these fine sights?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sister, in seriousness you yet are young and fair, a fair young maid and apt.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Apt?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Exceeding apt, apt to be drawn to.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: To what?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: To that you should not be, 'tis no dispraise,
She is not bad that hath desire to ill,
But she that hath no power to rule that will:
For there you shall be wooed in other kinds
Then yet your years have known, the chiefest men
Will seem to throw themselves
As vassals at your service, kiss your hand,
Prepare you banquets, masks, shows, all enticements
That wit and lust together can devise,
To draw a lady from the state of grace
to an old lady widow's gallery;
And they will praise your virtues, beware that,
The only way to turn a woman whore,
Is to commend her chastity: you'll go?

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: I would go, if it were but only to show you, that I could be there, and be moved with none of these tricks.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Your servants are ready?

sp.speaker: Oria
sp.p: An hour since

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Well, if you come off clear from this hot service,
Your praise shall be the greater. Farewell sister.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Farewell brother.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p:
Once more, if you stay in the presence till candlelight, keep on the foreside oth' curtain; and do you hear, take heed of the old bawd, in the cloth of tissue-sleeves, and the knit mittins. Farewell sister. Exit Oria.now am I idle, I would I had been a scholar, that I might a studied now: the punishment of meaner men is, they have too much to do; our only misery is, that without company we know not what to do; I must take some of the common courses of our nobility; which is thus: if I can find no company that likes me, pluck off my hatband, throw an old cloak over my face, and as if I would not be known, walk hastily through the streets, till I be discovered; then there goes count such a one, says one; there goes count such a one, says another: look how fast he goes, says a third; there's some great matters in hand questionless, says a fourth; when all my business is to have them say so: this hath been used; or if I can find any company, I'll after dinner to the stage, to see a play; where, when I first enter, you shall have a murmur in the house, every one that does not know, cries, what noble man is that; all the gallants on the stage rise, vail to me, kiss their hand, offer me their places: then I pick out some one, whom I please to grace among the rest, take his seat, use it, throw my cloak over my face, and laugh at him: the poor gentleman imagines himself most highly graced, thinks all the
auditors esteem him one of my bosom friends, and in right special regard with me. But here comes a gentleman, that I hope will make me better sport, than either street and stage fooleries. Enter Lazarello and boy.this man loves to eat good meat, always provided he do not pay for it himself: he goes by the name of the Hungary courtier; marry, because I think that name will not sufficiently distinguish him, for no doubt he hath more fellows there, his name is Lazarello, he is none of these same ordinary eaters, that will devour three breakfasts, and as many dinners, without any prejudice to their beavers, drinkings or suppers; but he hath a more courtly kind of hunger, and doth hunt more after novelty, than plenty, I'll overhear him.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: O thou most itching kindly appetite,
Which every creature in his stomach feels;
Oh leave, leave yet at last thus to torment me.
Three several salads have I sacrificed,
Bedewed with precious oil and vinegar
Already to appease thy greedy wrath. Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Will the count speak with me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: One of his gentlemen is gone to inform him of your coming sir.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: There is no way left for me to compass this fish head, but by being presently made known to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That will be hard sir.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: When I have tasted of this sacred dish,
Then shall my bones rest in my father's tomb
In peace, then shall I die most willingly,
And as a dish be served to satisfy
Death's hunger, and I will be buried thus:
My beer shall be a charger born by four,
The coffin where I lie, a powdering tub,
Bestrewed with lettuce, and cool salad herbs,
My winding sheet of tanseyes, the black guard
Shall be my solemn mourners, and in stead
of ceremonies, wholesome burial prayers:
A printed dirge in rhyme, shall bury me
In stead of tears, let them pour capon sauce
Upon my hearse, and salt in stead of dust,
Manchets for stones, for other glorious shields
Give me a voider, and above my hearse
For a trutch sword, my naked knife stuck up.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Master, the count is here.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Where? my lord I do beseech you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You're very welcome sir, I pray you stand up, you shall dine with me.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: I do beseech your lordship by the love I still have born to your honourable house.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir, what need all this? you shall dine with me, I pray rise.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Perhaps your lordship takes me for one of these same fellows, that do as it were respect victuals.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O sir, by no means.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Your lordship has often promised, that whensoever I should affect greatness, your own hand should help to raise me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And so much still assure yourself of.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: And though I must confess, I have ever shunned popularity by the example of others, yet I do now feel myself a little ambitious, your lordship is great, and though young, yet a privy counsellor.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I pray you sir leap into the matter, what would you have me do for you?

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: I would entreat your lordship to make me known to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: When sir?

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Suddenly my lord, I would have you present me unto him this morning.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: It shall be done, but for what virtues, would you have him take notice of you?

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p:
Your lordship shall know that presently. 'tis pity of this fellow, he is of good wit, and sufficient understanding,
when he is not troubled with this greedy worm.

sp.speaker: Lazar.
sp.p: Faith, you may entreat him to take notice of me for any thing; for being an excellent farrier, for playing well at span-counter, or sticking knives in walls, for being impudent, or for nothing; why may not I be a favourite on the sudden, I see nothing against it.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Not so sir, I know you have not the face to be a favourite on the sudden.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Why then you shall present me as a gentleman well qualified, or one extraordinary seen in divers strange mysteries.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: In what sir? as how?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Marry as thus â€”

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yonder's my old spirit, that hath haunted me daily, ever since I was a privy counsellor, I must be rid of him, I pray you stay there, I am a little busy, I will speak with you presently.

sp.speaker: Lazar.
sp.p: You shall bring me in, and after a little other talk, taking me by the hand, you shall utter these words to the Duke: may it please your grace, to take note of a gentleman, well read, deeply learned, and thoroughly grounded in the hidden knowledge of all salads and potherbs whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Twill be rare, if you will walk before sir, I will overtake you instantly.

sp.speaker: Lazar.
sp.p: Your lordship's ever.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
This fellow is a kind of informer, one that lives in alehouses, and taverns, and because he perceives some worthy men in this land, with much labour and great expense, to have discovered things dangerously hanging over the state; he thinks to discover as much out of the talk of drunkards in tap-houses: he brings me informations, picked out of broken words, in men's common talk, which with his malicious misapplication, he hopes will seem dangerous, he doth besides bring me the names of all the young gentlemen in the city, that use ordinaries, or taverns, talking (To my thinking) only as the freedom of their youth teach them, without any
further ends; for dangerous and seditious spirits, he is besides an arrant whoremaster, as any is in Milan, of a lay man. I will not meddle with the clergy, he is parcel lawyer, and in my conscience much of their religion, I must put upon him some piece of service; come hither sir, what have you to do with me?

sp.speaker: Intelligencer
sp.p: Little my lord, I only come to know how your lordship would employ me.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Observed you that gentleman, that parted from me but now.

sp.speaker: Intelligencer
sp.p: I saw him now my lord.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: I was sending for your, I have talked with this man, and I do find him dangerous.

sp.speaker: Intelligencer
sp.p: Is your lordship in earnest?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Hark you sir, there may perhaps be some within earshot.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Sirrah will you venture your life, the Duke hath sent the fish head to my lord?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir if he have not, kill me, do what you will with me.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: How uncertain is the state of all mortal things? I have these crosses from my cradle, from my very cradle, in so much that I do begin to grow desperate: fortune I do despise thee, do thy worst; yet when I do better gather myself together, I do find it is rather the part of a wise man, to prevent the storms of fortune by stirring, than to suffer them by standing still, to power themselves upon his naked body. I will about it.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Who's within there? Enter a servingmanlet this gentleman out at the back door, forget not my instructions, if you find any thing dangerous; trouble not yourself, to find out me, but carry your informations to the lord Lucio, he is a man grave and well experienced in these businesses.

sp.speaker: Intelligencer
sp.p: Your lordship's servant.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Will it please your worship walk?

sp.speaker: ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
sp.p: Sir I was coming, I will overtake you.

sp.speaker: Lazar.
sp.p: I will attend you over against the lord Gonderino's house.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You shall not attend there long.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Thither must I to see my love's face, the chaste virgin head
Of a dear fish, yet pure and underflowered,
Not known of man, no bred rough country hand,
Hath once touched thee, no panders withered paw,
Nor an un-napkined lawyer's greasy fist,
Hath once slubbered thee: no lady's supple hand,
Washed o'er with urine, hath yet seized on thee
With her two nimble talents: no court hand,
Whom his own natural filth, or change of air,
Hath bedecked with scabs, hath marred thy whiter grace:
Oh let it be thought lawful then for me,
To crop the flower of thy virginity.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: This day I am for fools, I am all theirs,
Though like to our young wanton cockered heirs,
Who do affect those men above the rest,
In whose base company they still are best:
I do not with much labour strive to be
The wisest ever in the company:
But for a fool, our wisdom oft amends,
As enemies do teach us more than friends.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: My lord:

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Here's one hath brought you a present.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: From whom, from a woman? if it be from a woman, bid him carry it back, and tell her she's a whore: what is it?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: A fish head my lord.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: What fish head?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I did not ask that my lord.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Whence comes it?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: From the court.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: O 'tis a codshead.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: No my lord, 'tis some strange head, it comes from the Duke.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Let it be carried to my mercer, I do owe him money for silks, stop his mouth with that. Exit Seru.was there ever any man that hated his wife after death but I? and for her sake all women, women that were created only for the preservation of little dogs.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: My lord, the counts sister being overtaken in the streets, with a great hailstorm, is light at your gate, and desires Rome till the storm be overpast.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Is she a woman?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I my lord I think so.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I have none for her then: bid her get her gone, tell her she is not welcome.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: My lord, she is now coming up.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: She shall not come up, tell her any thing, tell her I have but one great room in my house, and I am now in it at the close stool.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: She's here my lord.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: O impudence of women, I can keep dogs out of my house, or I can defend my house against thieves, but I cannot keep out women. Enter Oriana, a waiting woman, and a page. now madam, what hath your ladyship to say to me?

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: My lord, I was bold to crave the help of your house against the storm.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Your ladyship's boldness in coming, will be impudence in staying, for you are most unwelcome.

sp.speaker: Oriana.
sp.p: O my lord!

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Do you laugh, by the hate I bear to you, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: You're merry my lord.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Let me laugh to death if I be, or can be whilst thou art here, or livest, or any of thy sex.

sp.speaker: Oriana.
sp.p: I commend your lordship.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Do you commend me? why do you commend me? I give you no such cause: thou art a filthy impudent whore; a woman, a very woman.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Begotten when thy father was drunk.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Your lordship hath a good wit.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: How? what have I good wit?

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Come my lord, I have heard before of your lordship's merry vain in jesting against our sex, which I being desirous to hear, made me rather choose your lordship's house, than any other, but I know I am welcome.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Let me not live if you be: methinks it doth not become you, to come to my house, being a stranger to you. I have no woman in my house, to entertain you, nor to show you your chamber; why should you come to me? I have no galleries, nor banqueting houses, nor bawdy pictures to show your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Believe me, this your lordship's plainness makes me think myself more welcome, then if you had sworn by all the pretty court oaths that are, I had been welcomer than your soul to your body.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Now she's in talking, treason will get her out, I durst sooner undertake to talk an intelligencer out of the room, and speak more than he durst hear, than talk a woman out of my company.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: My lord, the Duke being in the streets, and the storm continuing, is entered your gate, and now coming up.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p:
The Duke! now I know your arrant madam; you have plots and private meetings in hand: why do you choose my house, are you ashamed to go to't in the old coupling place, though it be less suspicious here; for no christian will suspect a woman to be in my house, yet you may do it cleanlier there, for there is a care had of those businesses; and wheresoever you remove, your great
maintainer and you shall have your lodgings directly opposite, it is but putting on your nightgown, and your slippers; madam, you understand me?

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Before I would not understand him, but now he speaks riddles to me indeed.

div.stage: Enter the Duke, Arrigo, and Lucio.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Was a strange hailstorm.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: Was exceeding strange.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Good morrow to your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Good morrow Gondarino.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Justice great prince.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why should you beg for justice, I never did you wrong; what's the offendor?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: A woman.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.p: O I know your ancient quarrel against that sex; but what heinous crime hath she committed?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: She hath gone abroad.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What? it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: She hath done it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How? I never heard of any woman that did so before.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: If she have not laid by that modesty
That should attend a virgin, and quite void
Of shame, hath left the house where she was born,
As they should never do; let me endure
The pains that she should suffer.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Hath she so? which is the woman?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: This, this.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How Arrigo? Lucio?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: I than it is a plot, no prince alive
Shall force me make my house, a brothel house;
Not for the sins, but for the woman's sake,
I will not have her in my doors so long:
Will they make my house as bawdy as their own are?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Is it not Oriana?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Sister to count valour?

sp.speaker: Arri.
sp.p: The very same.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: She that I love?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: She that you love.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I do suspect.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: So do I.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This fellow to be but a counterfeit,
One that doth seem to loathe all woman kind,
To hate himself, because he hath some part
Of woman in him; seems not to endure
To see, or to be seen of any woman,
Only, because he knows it is their nature
To wish to taste that which is most forbidden:
And with this show, he may the better compass
(And with far less suspicion) his base ends.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: Upon my life 'tis so.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And I do know,
Before his slain wife gave him that offence,
He was the greatest servant to that sex,
That ever was; what doth this lady here
With him alone? why should he rail at her to me?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: Because your grace might not suspect.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Was so: I do love her strangely;
I would fain know the truth: counsel me. They 3. whisper

div.stage: Enter count, Lazarello, and his boy.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: It falls out better than we could expect sir, that we should find the Duke and my lord Gondarino together, both which you desire to be acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Lazar.
sp.p:
Was very happy: boy, go down into the kitchen, and see if you can spy that same; I am now in some hope: I have methinks a kind of fever upon me,Exit boy.a certain gloominess within me, doubting as it were, betwixt two passions; there is no young maid, upon her wedding night, when her husband sets first foot in the bed, blushes, and looks pale again, oftener than I do now. There is no poet acquainted with more shakings and
quakings, towards the latter end of this new play, when he's in that case, that he stands peeping betwixt the curtains, so fearfully, that a bottle of ale cannot be opened, but he thinks somebody hisses, than I am at this instant.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Are they in consultation, if they be, either my young Duke hath gotten some bastard, and is persuading my knight yonder, to father the child, and marry the wench, or else some cockpit is to be built.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: My lord? what noble man's that?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: His name is Lucio, 'tis he that was made a lord at the request of some of his friends for his wife's sake, he affects to be a great statesman, and thinks it consists in night caps, and jewels, and toothpicks?

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: And what's that other?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: A knight sir, that pleaseth the Duke to favour, and to raise to some extraordinary fortunes, he can make as good men as himself, every day in the week and doth â€”

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: For what was he raised.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Truly sir, I am not able to say directly, for what; but for wearing of red breeches as I take it, he's a brave man, he will spend three knighthoods at a supper without trumpets.

sp.speaker: Laza
sp.p: My lord I'll talk with him, for I have a friend, that would gladly receive the humour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: If he have the itch of knighthood upon him, let him repair to that physician, he'll cure him: but I will give you a note; is your friend fat or lean?

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Something fat.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Twill be the worse for him.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: I hope that's not material.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Very much, for there is an impost set upon knighthoods, and your friend shall pay a noble in the pound.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I do not like examinations,
We shall find out the truth more easily,
Some other way less noted, and that course,
should not be used, till we be sure to prove
Some thing directly, for when they perceive
Themselves suspected, they will then provide
More warily to answer.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Doth she know your grace doth love her.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: She hath never heard it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then thus my lord;They whisper again.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: What's he that walks alone so sadly with his hands behind him?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The lord of the house, he that you desire to be acquainted with, he doth hate women for the same cause that I love them.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: For that which apes want: you perceive me sir?

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: And is he sad, can he be sad, that hath so rich a gem under his roof, as that which I do follow? What young ladies that?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Which: have I mine eye sight perfect, 'tis my sister, did I say the Duke had a bastard? what should she make here with him, and his council; she hath no papers in her hand, to petition to them, she hath never a husband in prison, whose release she might sue for: that's a fine trick for a wench; to get her husband clapped up, that she may more freely, and with less suspicion, visit the private studies of men in authority. Now I do discover their consultation, yond fellow is a pandar without all salvation; but let me not condemn her too rashly, without weighing the matter; she's a young lady, she went forth early this morning with a waiting woman, and a page, or so: this is no garden house, in my conscience she went forth with no dishonest intent; for she did not pretend going to any sermon in the further end of the city: neither went she to see any odd old gentlewoman, that mourns for the death of her husband, or the loss of her friend, and must have young ladies come to comfort her: those are the damnable bawds, 'twas no set meeting certainly: for there was no wafer-woman
with her, these three days, on my knowledge: I'll talk with her: good morrow my lord.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: You're welcome sir: here's her brother come now to do a kind office for his sister, is it not strange?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am glad to meet you here sister.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: I thank you good brother: and if you doubt of of the cause of my coming, I can satisfy you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No faith, I dare trust thee, I do suspect thou art honest, for it is so rare a thing to be honest amongst you, that some one man in an age, may perhaps suspect some two women to be honest, but never believe it verily.

sp.speaker: Luci
sp.p: Let your return be sudden.

sp.speaker: Arri.
sp.p: Unsuspected by them.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: It shall, so shall I best perceive their love, if there be any, farewell.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Let me entreat your grace to stay a little,
To know a gentleman, to whom yourself
Is much beholding, he hath made the sport
For your whole court these 8. years, on my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: His name?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Lazarello.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: I heard of him this morning, which is he?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Lazarello, pluck up thy spirits, thy fortunes are now raising, the Duke calls for thee, and thou shalt be acquainted with him.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: He's going away, and I must of necessity stay here, upon business.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis all one, thou shalt know him first.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Stay a little, if he should offer to take me away with him, and by that means I should lose that I seek for; but if he should, I will not go with him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Lazarello the Duke stays, wilt thou lose this opportunity?

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: How must I speak to him?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l:
'Twas well thought of: you must not talk to him, as you do to an ordinary man, honest plain sense; but you must wind about him: for example, if he should ask
you what o'clock it is, you must not say; if it please your grace, 'tis nine, but thus; thrice three o'clock , so please my sovereign, or thus; look how many muses there doth dwell,
Upon the sweet banks of the learned well;
And just so many strokes the clock hath struck,
And so forth, and you must now and then enter into a description.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: I hope I shall do it.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Come: may it please your grace to take note of a gentleman, well seen, deeply read, and thoroughly grounded in the hidden knowledge of all salads and potherbs whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: I shall desire to know him more inwardly.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: I kiss the oxhide of your grace's foot.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Very well: will your grace question him a little?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: How old are you?

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: Full eight and twenty several almanacs
Hath been compiled, all for several years,
Since first I drew this breath, four prenticeships
Have I most truly served in this world:
And eight and twenty times hath Phoebus car
Run out his yearly course since.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: I understand you sir.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: How like an ignorant poet he talks.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: You are eight and twenty year old? what time of the day do you hold it to be?

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: About the time that mortals whet their knives
On thresholds, on their shoe soles, and on stairs:
Now bread is grating, and the testy cook
Hath much to do now, now the tables all.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: 'Tis almost dinner time?

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Your grace doth apprehend me very rightly.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Your grace shall find him in your further conference grave, wise, courtly, and scholar like, understandingly read in the necessities of the life of man. He knows that man is mortal by his birth; he knows that men must die, and therefore live;
he knows that man must live, and therefore eat, and if it shall please your grace, to accompany yourself with him, I doubt not, but that he will at the least, make good my commendations.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Attend us Lazarello, we do want
Men of such action, as we have received you
Reported from your honourable friend.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Good my lord stand betwixt me and my overthrow, you know I am tied here, and may not depart, my gracious lord, so weighty are the business of mine own, which at this time do call upon me, that I will rather choose to die, than to neglect them.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay you shall well perceive, besides the virtues that I have already informed you off, he hath a stomach, which will stoop to no prince alive.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Sir at your best leisure, I shall thirst to see you.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: And I shall hunger for it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Till then farewell all.

sp.speaker: Gentleman count.
sp.p: Long life attend your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: I do not taste this sport, Arrigo, Lucio.

sp.speaker: Ar. Luci.
sp.p: We do attend.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: His grace is gone, and hath left his Helen with me, I am no pander for him, neither can I be won with the hope of gain, or the itching desire of tasting my lord's lechery to him, to keep her at (My house) or bring her in disguise, to his bed chamber.
sp.l: The twines of adders, and of scorpions
About my naked breast, will seem to me
More tickling than those clasps, which men adore;
The lustful, dull, ill spirited embraces
Of women; the much praysed Amazones,
Knowing their own infirmities so well,
Made of themselves a people, and what men
They take amongst them, they condemn to die,
Perceiving that their folly made them fit
To live no longer, that would willingly
Come in the worthless presence of a woman.
I will attend, and see what my young lord will do with his sister.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My lord; the fish head is gone again.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Whither.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I know whither my lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Keep it from Lazarello: sister shall I confer with you in private, to know the cause of the Duke's coming hither, I know he makes you acquainted with his business of state.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: He satisfy you brother, for I see you are jealous of me.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Now there shall be some course taken for her conveyance.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Lazarello, thou art happy, thy carriage hath begotten love, and that love hath brought forth fruits, thou art here in the company of a man honourable, that will help thee to taste of the bounties of the sea, and when thou hast so done, thou shalt retire thyself unto the court, and there taste of the delicates of the earth, and be great in the eyes of thy sovereign: now no more shalt thou need to scramble for thy meat, nor remove thy stomach with the court; but thy credit shall command thy hearts desire, and all novelties shall be sent as presents unto thee.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Good sister, when you see your own time, will you return home.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Yes brother, and not before.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: I will grow popular in this state, and overthrow the fortunes of a number, that live by extortion.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Lazarello, bestir thyself nimbly and suddenly, and hear me with patience. to hear.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Let me not fall from myself; speak I am bound

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: So art thou to revenge, when thou shalt hear the fish head is gone, and we know not whither.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: I will not curse, nor swear, nor rage, nor rail,
Nor with contemptuous tongue, accuse my fate;
though I might justly do it, nor will I
Wish myself uncreated for this evil:
Shall I entreat your lordship to be seen
A little longer in the company
Of a man crossed by fortune.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I hate to leave my friend in his extremities.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: 'Tis noble in you, than I take your hand,
And do protest, I do not follow this
For any malice, or for private ends,
But with a love, as gentle and as chaste,
As that a brother to his sister bears:
And if I see this fish head yet unknown,
The last words that my dying father spoke,
Before his eyestrings broke, shall not of me
So often be remembered, as our meeting,
Fortune attend me, as my ends are just,
Full of pure love, and free from servile lust.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Farewell my lord, I was entreated to invite your lordship to a lady's upsitting.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: O my ears, why madam, will not you follow your brother, you are waited for by great men, he'll bring you to him.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: I'm very well my lord, you do mistake me, if you think I affect greater company than yourself.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: What madness possesseth thee, that thou canst imagine me a fit man to entertain ladies; I tell thee, I do use to tear their hair, to kick them, and to twinge their noses, if they be not careful in avoiding me.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Your lordship may descant upon your own behaviour as please you, but I protest, so sweet and courtly it appears in my eye, that I mean not to leave you yet.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I shall grow rough.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: A rough carriage is best in a man, I'll dine with you my lord.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Why I will starve thee, thou shalt have nothing.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: I have heard of your lordships nothing, I'll put that to the venture.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Well, thou shalt have meat, I'll send it to thee.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: I'll keep no state my lord, neither do I mourn, I'll dine with you.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Is such a thing as this allowed to live:
What power hath let thee lose upon the earth
To plague us for our sins? out of my doors.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: I would your lordship did but see how well
This fury doth become you, it doth show
So near the life, as it were natural.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: O thou damned woman, I will fly the vengeance
That hangs above thee, follow if thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: I must not leave this fellow, I will torment him to madness,
To teach his passions against kind to move,
The more he hates, the more I'll seem to love.

div.stage: Enter Pandar and Mercer a citizen.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.l: Sir, what may be done by art shall be done,
I wear not this black cloak for nothing.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Perform this, help me to this great heir by learning, and you shall want no black cloaks, taffeties, silk grogerams, satins and velvets are mine, they shall be yours; perform what you have promised, and you shall make me a lover of sciences, I will study the learned languages, and keep my shop-book in Latin.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Trouble me not now, I will not fail you within this hour at your shop.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Let art have her course.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: 'Tis well spoken, madonna.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Hast thou brought me any customers.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: What the devil dost thou in black.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: As all solemn professors of settled courses, do cover my knavery with it: will you marry a citizen, reasonably rich, and unreasonably foolish, silks in his shop, money in his purse, and no wit in his head?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Out upon him, I could have been otherwise than so, there was a knight swore he would have had me, if I would have lent him but forty shillings to have redeemed his cloak, to go to church in.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Then your waistcoat waiter shall have him, call her in?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Francessina?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Anon?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Get you to the church, and shrive yourself,
For you shall be richly married anon.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: And get you after her, I will work upon my citizen whilst he is warm, I must nor suffer him to consult with his neighbours, the openest fools are hardly cozened, if they once grow jealous.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Save me ye better powers, let me not fall
Between the loose embracements of a woman:
Heaven, if my sins be ripe grown to a head,
And must attend your vengeance: I beg not to divert my fate,
Or to reprieve a while thy punishment
Only I crave, and hear me equal heavens,
Let not your furious rod, that must afflict me,
Be that imperfect piece of nature,
That art makes up, woman, unsatiate woman.
Had we not knowing souls, at first infused
To teach a difference, twixt extremes and goods?
Were we not made ourselves, free, unconfined
Commanders of our own affections:
And can it be, that this most perfect creature,
This image of his maker, well squared man,
Should leave the handfast, that he had of grace,
To fall into a woman's easy arms.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Now Venus be my speed, inspire me with all the several subtle temptations, that thou hast already given, or haste in store hereafter to bestow upon our sex: grant that I may apply that physic that is most apt to work upon him: whether he will soonest be moved with wantonness, singing, dancing, or being passionate, with scorn, or with sad and serious looks, cunningly mingled with sighs, with smiling, lisping, kissing the hand, and making short curtsies; or with whatsoever other nimble power, he may be caught: do thou infuse into me, and when I have him, I will sacrifice him up to thee.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: It comes again; new apparitions,
And tempting spirits: stand and reveal thyself,
Tell why thou followest me? I fear thee
As I fear the place thou camest from: hell.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: My lord, I am a woman, and such a one â€”

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: That I hate truly, thou hadst better been a devil. women.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Why my unpatient lord?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Devils were once good, there they excelled you

sp.speaker: Orian
sp.l: Can ye be so uneasy, can ye freeze, and
Such a summer's heat so ready
To dissolve, nay gentle lord, turn not away in scorn,
Nor hold me less fair than I am: look on these checks,
They have yet enough of nature, true complexion,
If to be red and white, a forehead high,
An easy melting lip, a speaking eye,
And such a tongue, whose language takes the ear
Of strict religion, and men most austere:
If these may hope to please, look here.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: This woman with entreaty would show all,
Lady there lies your way, I pray ye farewell.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.l: You're yet too harsh, to dissonant.
There's no true music in your words, my lord.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: What shall I give thee to be gone?
Here's ta, and than wants lodging, take my house, 'tis big enough, 'tis shine own, 'twill hold five lecherous lords, and their lackeys without discovery: there's stoves and bathing tubs.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Dear lord: you're too wild.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Shalt have a doctor too, thou shalt, about six and twenty, 'tis a pleasing age; or I can help thee to a handsome usher: or if thou lack'st a page, I'll give thee one, prithee keep house, and leave me.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: I do confess I am too easy, too much woman,
Not coy enough to take affection,
Yet I can frown and nip a passion
Even in the bud: I can say
Men please their present heats; then please to leave us.
I can hold off, and by my chemic power
Draw sonnets, from the melting lover's brain.
Ay-mees, and elegies: yet to you my lord
My love, my better self, I put these off,
Doing that office, not befits our sex,
Entreat a man to love;
Are ye not yet relenting, ha' ye blood and spirit
In those veins, ye are no image, though ye be as hard.
As marble, sure ye have no liver, if ye had,
'T would send a lively and desiring heat
To every member; is not this miserable,
A thing so truly formed, shaped out by symmetry,
Has all the organs that belong to man,
And working to, yet to show all these
Like dead motions moving, upon wires,
Then good my lord, leave off what you have been,
And freely be what you were first intended for: a man.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Thou art a precious piece of sly damnation,
I will be deaf, I will lock up my ears,
Tempt me not, I will not love; if I do,

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Then I'll hate you.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Let me be anointed with honey, and turned into the sun,
To be stung to death with horseflies,
Heart thou, thou breeder, here I'll sit,
And in despite of thee I will say nothing.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Let me with your fair patience, sit beside you?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Madam, lady, tempter, tongue, woman, air,
look to me, I shall kick; I say again,
Look to me I shall kick.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: I cannot think your better knowledge can use a woman so uncivilly.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: I cannot think, I shall become a coxcomb,
To ha' my hare curled, by an idle finger,
My cheeks turn tabers, and be played upon,
Mine eyes looked babies in, and my nose blowed to my hand, mind
I say again I shall kick, sure I shall.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: 'Tis but your outside that you show: I know your
Never was guilty of so great a weakness,
Or could the tongues of all men joined together
Possess me with a thought of your dislike
My weakness were above a woman's, to fall off
From my affection, for one crack of thunder,
Oh would you could love my lord.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I would thou wouldst sit still, and say nothing: what madman let thee loose to do more mischief than a dozen whirlwinds, keep thy hands: in thy muff, and warm the idle worms in thy finger's ends will ye be doing still, will no entreating serve ye, no lawful warning, I must remove and leave your ladyship; nay never hope to stay me, for I will run, from that smooth, smiling, witching, cozening, tempting, damning face of thine, as far as I can find any land, where I will put myself into a daily course of curses for thee, and all thy family.

sp.speaker: Oriana.
sp.l: Nay good my lord sit still, I'll promise peace
And fouled mine arms up, let but mine eye discourse,
Or let my voice set to some pleasing cord, sound out
The sullen strains of my neglected love.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Sing till thou crack thy treble string in pieces,
And when thou hast done, put up thy pipes and walk,
Do any thing, sit still and tempt me not.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: I had rather sing at doors for bread, then sing to this fellow, but for hate: if this should be told in the court, that I begin to woe lords, what a troop of the untrust nobility should I have at my lodging tomorrow morning.

lg.l: Come sleep, and with thy sweet deceiving,
Lock me in delight a while,
All my fancies that from thence,Song.
All my powers of care bereaving.
Though but a shadow, but a sliding,
Let me know some little joy,
Oh let my joys, have some abiding.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Have you done your wassail, 'tis a handsome drowsy ditty I'll assure ye, now I had as lief here a cart cry, when her tail is cut off, as hear these lamentations, these lousy love-lays, these bewailments , you think you have caught me lady, you think I melt now, like a dish of May butter, and run, all into brine, and passion, yes, yes, I am taken, look how I cross my arms, look pale, and dwindle, and would cry, but for spoiling my face, we must part, nay we'll avoid all ceremony, no kissing lady, I desire to know your ladyship no more; death of my soul the Duke.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: God keep your lordship.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: From thee and all thy sex.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: I'll be the clerk and cry amen,
Your lordship's ever assured enemy Oriana.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: All the days good, attend your lordship.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We thank you Gonderino, is it possible,
Can belief lay hold on such a miracle,
To see thee, one that hath cloistered up all passion,

Turned wilful votary, and forsworn, converse with women
in company and fair discover, with the best beauty of Milan?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: 'Tis true, and if your grace that hath the sway
Of the whole state, will suffer this lewd sex,
These women, to pursue us to our homes,
Not to be prayed, nor to be railed away,
But they will woe, and dance, and sing,
And in a manner, looser than they are
By nature (Which should seem impossible)
To throw their arms, on our unwilling necks.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more, I can see through your visor, dissemble it no more,
Do not I know thou hast used all art,
To work upon the poor simplicity
Of this young maid, that yet hath known none ill?
Thinkst that damnation will fright those that woo
From oaths, and lies? but yet I think her chaste,
And will from thee, before thou shalt apply
Stronger temptations, bear her hence with me.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: My lord, I speak not this to gain new grace,
But howsoever you esteem my words,
My love and duty will not suffer me
To see you favour such a prostitute,
And I stand by dumb; without rack, torture,
Or strappado, I'll unrip myself,
I do confess I was in company, with that pleasing piece of frailty, that we call woman; I do confess after a long and tedious siege, I yielded.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Forward.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Faith my lord to come quickly to the point, the woman you saw with me is a whore; an arrant whore.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Was she not count Valores' sister?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Yes, that count Valores' sister in naught.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Thou dar'st not say so.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Not, if it be distasting to your lordship, but give me freedom, and I dare maintain, she has embraced this body, and grown to it as close, as the hot youthful vine to the elm.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Twice have I seen her with thee twice my thoughts were prompted by mine eye, to hold thy strictness false and imposterous: is this your mewing up, your strict retirement, your bitterness and gall against that sex: have I not heard thee say, thou wouldst sooner meet the basilisks dead doing eye, then meet a woman for an object: look it be true you tell me, or by our country's saint your head goes off: if thou prove a whore, no woman's face shall ever move me more.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: So, so, 'tis as it should be, are women grown so mankind? Must they be wooing, I have a plot shall blow her up, she flies, she mounts, I'll teach her ladyship to dare my fury, I will be known and feared, and more truly hated of women than an eunuch. Enter Oriana.she's here again, good Gaul be patient, for I must dissemble.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Now my cold frosty lord, my woman hater, you that have sworn an everlasting hate to all our sex: by my troth good lord, and as I am yet a maid, my think 'twas excellent sport to hear your honour swear out an alphabet, chafe nobly like a general, kick like a resty jade and make ill faces: did your good honour think I was in love? where did I first begin to take that heat? from those two radiant eyes, that piercing sight? o they were lovely, if the balls stood right; and there's a leg made out of a dainty staff, where the gods be thanked, there is calf enough.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Pardon him lady that is now a convertite,
Your beauty like a saint hath wrought this wonder.

sp.speaker: Oriana.
sp.p: A lass, has it been pricked at the heart, is the stomach come down, will it rail no more at women, and call 'em devils, she cats, and goblins.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p:
He that shall marry thee, had better spend the poor remainder of his days in a dung-barge, for two pence a week, and find himself:
down again spleen, I prithee down again, shall I find favour lady? shall at length my true unfeigned penitence get pardon for my harsh unseasoned follies? I am no more an atheist, no, I do acknowledge, that dread powerful deity, and his all quickening heats, burn in my breast: o be not as I was, hard, unrelenting; but as I am, be partner of my fires.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Sure we shall have store of larks, the skies will not hold up long, I should have looked as soon for frost in the dog days, or another inundation, as hoped this strange conversion above miracle: let me look upon your lordship; is your name Gondarino, are you Milan's general, that great bugbear bloodybones, at whose very name all women, from the lady to the laundress, shake like a cold fit.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Good patience help me, this fever will enrage my blood again: madam I am that man; I am even he, that once did owe unreconciled hate to you, and all that bear the name of woman: I am the man, that wronged your honour to the Duke, I am he that said you were unchaste, and prostitute; yet I am he, that dare deny all this.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Your big nobility is very merry.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Lady 'tis true that I have wronged you thus,
And my contrition is as true as that,
Yet have I found a means to make all good again,
I do beseech your beauty, not for myself,
My merits are yet in conception,
But for your honour's safety, and my zeal
Retire a while, whilst I unsay myself unto the Duke,
And cast out that evil spirit, I have possessed him with,
I have a house conveniently private.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.p: Lord, thou hast wronged my innocence, but thy confession hath gained thee faith.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: By the true honest service, that I owe those eyes, strangely,
My meaning is as spotless as my faith.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: The Duke doubt mine honour? A may judge
'Twill not be long, before I'll be enlarged again.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: A day or two.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Mine own servants shall attend me.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Your ladyship's command is good.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Look you be true.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Else let me lose the hopes my soul aspires to: I will be a scourge to all females in my life, and after my death, the name of Gondarino shall be terrible to the mighty women of the earth; they shall shake at my name, and at the sound of it, their knees shall knock together; and they shall run into nunneries, for they and I are beyond all hope irreconcilable: for if I could endure an ear with a hole in't, or a pleated lock, or a bareheaded coachman, that sits like a sign, where great ladies are to be sold within; agreement betwixt us, were not to be despaired of; if I could be but brought to endure to see women, I would have them come all once a week and kiss me, where witches do the devil in token of homage: I must not live here, I will to the court, and there pursue my plot; when it hath taken, women shall stand in awe, but of my look.

div.head: Actus iii. Scen. iii.
div.stage: Enter two intelligencers, discovering treason in the courtier's words.

sp.speaker: 1. Intel.
sp.p: There take your standing, be close and vigilant, here will I set myself, and let him look to his language, 'a shall know the Duke has more ears in court than two.

sp.speaker: 2. Intelligencer
sp.p: I'll quote him to a tittle, let him speak wisely, and plainly, and as hidden as a can, or I shall crush him, 'a shall not scape characters, though 'a speak Babel, I shall crush him: we have a fortune by this service hanging over us, that within this year or two, I hope we shall be called to be examiners, wear politic gowns guarded with copper lace, making great faces full of fear and office, our labours may deserve this.

sp.speaker: 1. Intelligencer
sp.p:
I hope it shall: why has not many men been raised from this worming trade, first to gain good access to great men, than to have commissions out for search, and
lastly, to be worthily named at a great arraignment: yes, and why not we? they that endeavour well deserve their fee. Close, close, 'a comes: mark well, and all goes well.

div.stage: Enter count, Lazarello, and his boy.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Farewell my hopes, my anchor now is broken,
Farewell my quondam joys, of which no token
Is now remaining, such is the sad mischance,
Where lady fortune leads the slippery dance.
Yet at the length, let me this favour have,
Give me my wishes, or a wished grave.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: The gods defend so brave and valiant maw,
Should slip into the never satiate jaw
Of black despair; no, thou shalt live and know
Thy full desires, hunger thy ancient foe,
Shall be subdued, those guts that daily tumble
Through air and appetite, shall cease to rumble:
And thou shalt now at length obtain thy dish,
That noble part, the sweet head of a fish.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Then am I greater than the Duke.

sp.speaker: 2. Intelligencer
sp.p: There, there's a notable piece of treason, greater than the Duke, mark that.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But how, or where, or when this shall be compassed, is yet out of my reach.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I am so truly miserable, that might I be now knocked ath' head, with all my heart I would forgive a dog killer.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yet do I see through this confusedness some little comfort.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: The plot my lord, as ere you can of a woman discover.

sp.speaker: 1. Intelligencer
sp.p: Plots, dangerous plots, I will deserve by this most liberally.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis from my head again.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: O that it would stand me, that I might fight, or have some venture for it, that I might be turned loose, to try my fortune amongst the whole fry in a college, or an inn of court, or scramble with the prisoners in the dungeon; nay were it set down in the outer court,
sp.l: And all the guard about it in a ring,
with their knives drawn, which were a dismal sight,
And after twenty leisurely were told,
I to be let loose, only in my shirt,
To try the valour, how much of the spoil,
I would recover from the enemy's mouths:
I would accept the challenge.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Let it go: hast not thou been held
To have some wit in the court, and to make fine jests
Upon country people in progress time, and
Wilt thou lose this opinion, for the cold head of a fish?
I say, let it go: I'll help thee to as good a dish of meat.

sp.speaker: Lazar.
sp.l: God let me not live, if I do not wonder
Men should talk so profanely:
But it is not in the power of loose words,
Of any vain or misbelieving man,
To make me dare to wrong thy purity,
Show me but any lady in the court,
That hath so full an eye, so sweet a breath,
So soft and white a flesh: this doth not lie
In almond gloves, nor ever hath been washed
In artificial baths; no traveller
That hath brought doctor home with him, hath dared
With all his waters, powders, fucuses,
To make thy lovely corpses sophisticate.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have it, 'tis now infused, be comforted.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Can there be that little hope yet left in nature? shall I once more erect up trophies? shall I enjoy the sight of my dear saint, and bless my palate with the best of creatures, ah good my lord, by whom I breathe again, shall I receive this being?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir, I have found by certain calculation, and settled revolution of the stars, the fish is sent by the lord Gondarino to his mercer, now 'tis a growing hope to know where 'tis.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: O 'tis far above the good of women, the pathic cannot yield more pleasing titillation.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
But how to compass it, search, East about, and
bang your brains, Lazarello, thou art to dull and heavy to deserve a blessing.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: My lord, I will not be idle; now Lazarello, think, think, think.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Yonder's my informer
And his fellow with table books, they nod at me
Upon my life, they have poor Lazarello that beats
His brains about no such weighty matter, in for
Treason before this â€”

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: My lord, what do you think, if I should shave myself, put on midwives apparel, come in with a handkercher, and beg a piece for a great bellied woman, or a sick child?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Good, very good.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Or corrupt the waiting prentice to betray the reversion.

sp.speaker: 1. Inte.
sp.p: There's another point in's plot, corrupt with money to betray: sure 'tis some fort a means: mark, have a care.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: And 'twere the bare vinegar 'tis eaten with, it would in some sort satisfy nature: but might I once attain the dish itself, though I cut out my means through swords and fire, through poison, through any thing that may make good my hopes.

sp.speaker: 2. Intelligencer
sp.p: Thanks to the gods, and our officiousness, the plots discovered, fire, steel, and poison, burn the palace, kill the Duke, and poison his privy counsel.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: To the mercers, let me see: how if before we can attain the means, to make up our acquaintance, the fish be eaten?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: If it be eaten, here a stands, that is the most dejected, most unfortunate, miserable, accursed, forsaken slave, this province yields: I will not sure outlive it, no I will die bravely, and like a roman; and after death, amid the Elysian shades, I'll meet my love again.

sp.speaker: 1. In.
sp.p: I will die bravely, like a roman: have a care, mark that: when he hath done all, he will kill himself.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Will no thing ease your appetite but this?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p:
No could the sea throw up his vastness,
and offer free his best inhabitants: 'twere not so much as a bare temptation to me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: If you could be drawn to affect beef, venison, or fowl, 'twould be far the better.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: I do beseech your lordship's patience,
I do confess that in this heat of blood,
I have contemned all dull and grosser meats,
But I protest, I do honour a chine of beef,
I do reverence a loin of veal,
But good my lord, give me leave a little to adore this:
But my good lord, would your lordship under colour
Of taking up some silks, go to the mercers, I would in
All humility attend your honour, where we may be invited,
If fortune stand propitious.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir you shall work me as you please.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Let it be suddenly, I do beseech your lordship, 'tis now upon the point of dinner time.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am all yours.

sp.speaker: 1. In.
sp.p: Come let us confer, inprimis 'a saith like a blasphemous villain, he is greater than the Duke, this peppers him, and there were nothing else.

sp.speaker: 2. In.
sp.p: Then 'a was naming plots; did ye not hear?

sp.speaker: 1. In.
sp.p: Yes but a fell from that, unto discovery, to corrupt by money, and so attain.

sp.speaker: 2. In.
sp.p: Ay, ay, a meant some fort, or citadel the Duke hath, his very face betrayed his meaning, oh he is a very subtle and a dangerous knave, but if a deal a god's name we shall worm him.

sp.speaker: 1. In.
sp.p: But now comes the stroke, the fatal blow, fire, sword, and poison, oh cannibal, thou bloody cannibal.

sp.speaker: 2. In.
sp.p: What had become of this poor state, had not we been?

sp.speaker: 1. In.
sp.p: Faith it had lyen buried in his own ashes; had not a greater hand been in't.

sp.speaker: 2. In.
sp.p:
But note the rascal's resolution, after th'acts done, because a would avoid all fear of torture, and cozen the law, a would kill himself? was there ever the like danger, brought to light in this age? sure we shall merit much, we shall be able to keep two men a piece, and a two hand sword
between us, we will live in favour of the state, betray our ten or twelve treasons a week, and the people shall fear us: come, to the lord Lucio, the sun shall not go down till a be hanged.

div.head: Actus 3. Scaena. 4.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Look to my shop, and if there come ever a scholar in black, let him speak with me, we that are shopkeepers in good trade, are so pestered, that we can scarce pick out an hour for our morning's meditation: and howsoever we are all accounted dull, and common jesting stocks, for your gallants; there are some of us, do not deserve it: for for my own part, I do begin to be given to my book, I love a scholar with my heart; for questionless there are marvelous things to be done by art: why sir, some of them will tell you what is become of horses, and silver spoons, and will make wenches dance naked to their beds: I am yet unmarried, and because some of our neighbours are said to be cuckolds, I will never marry without the consent of some of these scholars, that know what will come of it.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Are you busy sir?

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Never to you sir, nor to any of your coat. Sir is there any thing to be done by art, concerning the great heir we talked on?

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Will she, will she? she shall come running into my house at the farther corner, in sa marks street, betwixt three and four.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Betwixt three and four? she's brave in clothes; is she not?

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: O rich! rich! where should I get clothes to dress her in? help me invention: sir, that her running through the street, may be less noted, my art more shown, and your fear to speak with her less, she shall come in a white waistcoat, and â€”

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: What shall she?

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: And perhaps torn stockings, she hath left her old wont else.

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: Sir my lord Gonde. hath sent you a rare fish head.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p:
It comes right, all things suit right with me, since I
began to love scholars, you shall have it home with you, against she come: carry it to this gentleman's house.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: The fair white house at the farther corner at s. marks street, make haste, I must leave you too sir. I have two hours to study; buy a new accidence, and ply your book, and you shall want nothing, that all the scholars in the town can do for you.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Heaven prosper both our studies, what a dull slave was I, before I fell in love with this learning? not worthy to tread upon the earth, and what fresh hopes it hath put into me? I do hope within this twelvemonth , to be able by art, to serve the court with silks, and not undo myself; to trust knights, and yet get in my money again; to keep my wife brave, and yet she keep nobody else, so. Enter count, and Lazarello.your lordship is most honourably welcome, in regard of your nobility, but most especially in regard of your scholarship: did your lordship come openly?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir this cloak keeps me private, besides no man will suspect me to be in the company of this gentleman, with whom, I will desire you to be acquainted, he may prove a good customer to you.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: For plain silks and velvets.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Are you scholastical?

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Something addicted to the Muses.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I hope they will not dispute.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: You have no skill in the black art?

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: Sir yonder's a gentleman, inquires hastily for count valour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: For me? what is he?

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: One of your followers my lord I think.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Let him come in.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Shall I talk with you in private sir?

div.stage: Enter a messenger with a letter to the count. he reads.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Count come to the court, your business calls you thither, I will go, farewell sir, I'll see your silks some other time: farewell Lazarillo.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Will not your lordship take a piece of beef with me?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir I have greater business than eating; I will leave this gentleman with you.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: No, no, no, no: now do I feel that strained struggling within me, that I think I could prophesy.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: The gentleman is meditating.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Hunger, valour, love, ambition, are alike pleasing, and let our philosophers say what they will, are one kind of heat, only hunger is the safest, ambition is apt to fall; love and valour are not free from dangers, only hunger, begotten of some old limber courtier, in paned hose, and nursed by an attorney's wife, now so thriven, that he need not fear to be of the great Turks guard: is so free from all quarrels, and dangers, so full of hopes, joys, and ticklings, that my life is not so dear to me, as his acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, the fish head is gone.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: Then be thou henceforth dumb, with thy ill boding voice
Farewell Milan, fare well noble Duke,
Farewell my fellow courtiers all, with whom,
I have of yore made many a scrambling meal
In corners, behind arasses, on stairs,
And in the action often times have spoilt,
Our doublets and our hose, with liquid stuff:
Farewell you lusty archers of the guard,
To whom I now do give the bucklers up,
And never more with any of your coat
Will eat for wagers, now you happy be,
When this shall light upon you, think on me:
You sewers, carvers, ushers of the court
Surnamed gentle, for your fair demean,
Here I do take of you my last farewell,
May you stand stiffly in your proper places,
And execute your offices aright.
Farewell you maidens, with your mother eke,
Farewell you courtly chaplains that be there,
All good attend you, may you never more
marry your patron's lady's waiting-woman,
But may you raised be; by this my fall
May Lazarillo suffer for you all.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Sir, I was harkening to you.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I will hear nothing; I will break my knife, the ensign of my former happy state, knock out my teeth, have them hung at a barber's, and enter into religion.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why sir, I think, I know whether it is gone.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: See the rashness of man in his nature; whither? whither? I do unsay all that I have said, go on, go on: boy, I humble myself and follow thee; farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Not so sir, you shall take a piece of beef with me.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: By my fay, but you shall sir; in regard of your love to learning, and your skill in the black art.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I do hate learning, and I have no skill in the black art; I would I had.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Why your desire is sufficient to me, you shall stay.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: The most horrible, and detested curses that can be imagined; light upon all the professors of that art; may they be drunk, and when they go to conjure, and reel in the circle, may the spirits by them raised, tear am in pieces, and hang their quarters on old broken walls, and steeple tops.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: This speech of yours, shows you to have some skill in the science, wherefore in civility, I may not suffer you to depart empty.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: My stomach is up, I cannot endure it, I will fight in this quarrel, as soon as for my prince. Room, make way:Draws his rapierhunger commands, my valour must obey.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Is the Duke private?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: He is alone, but I think your lordship may enter.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Who's with the Duke?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: The count is new gone in, but the Duke will come forth, before you can be weary of waiting.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I will attend him here.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: I must wait without the door.

sp.speaker: Gond.
