sp.p: Doth he hope to clear his sister, she will come no more to my house, to laugh at me: I have sent her to a habitation, where when she shall be seen, it will set a gloss upon her name; yet upon my soul I have bestowed her amongst the purest hearted creatures of her sex, and the freest from dissimulation; for their deeds are all alike, only they dare speak, what the rest think: the women of this age, if there be any degrees of comparison amongst their sex, are worse than those of former times; for I have read of women, of that truth, spirit, and constancy, that were they now living, I should endure to see them: but I fear the writers of the time, belied them, for how familiar a thing is it with the poets of our age, to extol their whores, which they call mistresses, with heavenly praises? but I thank their furies, and their crazed brains, beyond belief: nay how many that would fain seem serious, have dedicated grave works to ladies toothless, hollow eyed, their hair shedding, purple faced, their nails apparently coming off; and the bridges of their noses broken down; and have called them the choice handy works of nature, the patterns of perfection, and the wonderment of women. Our women begin to swarm like bees in summer: as I came hither, there was no pair of stairs, no entry, no lobby, but was pestered with them: methinks there might be some course taken to destroy them.

div.stage: Enter Arrigo, and an old deaf country gentlewoman suitor to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Arrigo.
sp.p:
I do accept your money, walk here, and when the Duke comes out, you shall have fit opportunity to
deliver your petition to him.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: I thank you heartily, I pray you who's he that walks there?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: A lord, and a soldier, one in good favour with the Duke; if you could get him to deliver your petition â€”

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: What do you say sir?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: If you could get him to deliver your petition for you, or to second you, 'twere sure.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: I hope I shall live to requite your kindness.

sp.speaker: Arrig.
sp.p: You have already.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: May it please your lordship â€”

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: To consider the estate â€”

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: Of a poor oppressed country gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: No, it doth not please my lordship.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: First and foremost, I have had great injury, than I have been brought up to the town three times.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: A pox on him, that brought thee to the town.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: I thank your good lordship heartily; though I cannot hear well, I know it grieves you; and here we have been delayed, and sent down again, and fetched up again, and sent down again, to my great charge: and now at last they have fetched me up, and five of my daughters â€”

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Enough to damn five worlds.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: Handsome young women, though I say it, they are all without, if it please your lordship, I'll call them in.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Five women! how many of my senses should I have left me then? call in five devils first.
sp.l: No, I will rather walk with thee alone,
And hear thy tedious tale of injury,
And give thee answers; whisper in thine ear,
And make thee understand; through thy french-hood:
And all this with tame patience.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: I see your lordship does believe, that they are without, and I perceive you are much moved at our injury: here's a paper will tell you more.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: A way.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: It may be you had rather hear me tell it viva voce, as they say.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: O no, no, no, no, I have heard it before.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: Then you have heard of enough injury, for a poor gentlewoman to receive.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Never, never, but that it troubles my conscience, to wish any good to those women; I could afford them to be valiant, and able, that it might be no disgrace for a soldier to beat them.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: I hope your lordship will deliver my petition to his grace, and you may tell him withal â€”

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: What, I will deliver any thing against myself, to be rid on thee.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: That yesterday, about three o'clock , in the afternoon , I met my adversary.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Give me thy paper, he can abide no long tales.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: 'Tis very short my lord, and I demanding of him â€”

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I'll tell him that shall serve thy turn.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I'll tell him that shall serve thy turn, be gone: man never doth remember how great his offences are, till he do meet with one of you, that plagues him for them: why should women only above all other creatures that were created for the benefit of man, have the use of speech? or why should any deed of theirs, done by their fleshly appetites, be disgraceful to their owners? nay, why should not an act done by any beast I keep, against my consent, disparage me as much as that of theirs?

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: Here's some few angels for your lordship.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Again? yet more torments?

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: Indeed you shall have them.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Keep off.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: A small gratuity for your kindness.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Hold away.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p:
Why then I thank your lordship, I'll gather them up
again, and I'll be sworn, it is the first money, that was refused, since I came to the court.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: What can she devise to say more?

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: Truly I would have willingly parted with them to your lordship.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I believe it, I believe it.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: But since it is thus â€”

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: More yet.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: I will attend without, and expect an answer.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Do, begone, and thou shalt expect, and have any thing, thou shalt have thy answer from him; and he were best to give thee a good one at first, for thy deaf importunity, will conquer him too, in the end.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: God bless your lordship, and all that favour poor distressed country gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: All the diseases of man, light upon them that do, and upon me when I do; a week of such days, would either make me stark mad, or tame me: yonder other woman that I have sure enough, shall answer for thy sins: dare they incense me still, I will make them fear as much to be ignorant of me and my moods, as men are to be ignorant of the law they live under. Who's there? My blood grew cold, I began to fear my suitors return; 'tis the Duke.

div.stage: Enter the Duke and the count.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I know her chaste, though she be young and free,
And is not of that forced behaviour
That many others are, and that this lord,
Out of the boundless malice to the sex,
Hath thrown this scandal on her.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Fortune, befriended me against my will, with this good old country gentlewoman; I beseech your grace, to view favourably the petition of a wronged gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What Gondarino, are you become a petitioner for your enemies?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p:
My lord, they are no enemies of mine, I confess the better to cover my deeds, which sometimes were loose
enough, I pretended it, as it is wisdom, to keep close our incontinency; but since you have discovered me, I will no more put on that vizard, but will as freely open all my thoughts to you, as to my confessor.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What say you to this?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: He that confesses, he did once dissemble,
I'll never trust his words, can you imagine
A maid, whose beauty could not suffer her
To live thus long untempted, by the noblest,
Richest, and cunningest masters in that art,
And yet hath ever held a fair repute;
Could in one morning, and by him be brought,
To forget all her virtue, and turn whore?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: I would I had some other talk in hand,
Than to accuse a sister to her brother;
Nor do I mean it for a public scandal,
Unless by urging me, you make it so.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I will read this at better leisure: Gondarino, where is the lady?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: At his house.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: No, she is departed thence.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Urge it not thus, or let me be excused,
If what I speak betray her chastity,
And both increase my sorrow, and your own.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Fear me not so, if she deserve the fame
Which she hath gotten, I would have it published,
Brand her myself, and whip her through the city:
I wish those of my blood that do offend,
Should be more strictly punished, than my foes.
Let it be proved.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Gondarino, thou shalt prove it, or suffer worse than she should do.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Then pardon me, if I betray the faults
Of one, I love more dear then myself,
Since opening hers, I shall betray mine own:
But I will bring you, where she now intends
not to be virtuous: pride and wantonness,
That are true friends indeed, though no in show,
Have entered on her heart, there she doth bathe,
And sleek her hair, and practise cunning looks,
To entertain me with; and hath her thoughts
As full of lust, as ever you did think
Them full of modesty.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Gondarino, lead on, we'll follow thee.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Here hope I to meet my citizen, and here hopes he to meet his scholar; I am sure I am grave enough, to his eyes, and knave enough to deceive him: I am believed to conjure, raise storms, and devils, by whose power I can do wonders; let him believe so still, belief hurts no man: I have an honest black cloak, for my knavery, and a general pardon for his foolery, from this present day, till the day of his breaking. Is't not a misery, and the greatest of our age, to see a handsome, young, fair enough, and well mounted wench, humble herself, in an old stammel petticoat, standing possessed of no more fringe than the street can allow her: her upper parts so poor and wanting, that ye may see her bones through her bodies: shoes she would have, if her captain were come over, and is content the while to devote herself to ancient slippers. These premises well considered, gentlemen will move, they make me melt I promise ye, they stir me much; and were't not for my smooth, soft, silken citizen, I would quit this transitory trade, get me an everlasting robe, fear up my conscience, and turn sergeant. But here 'a comes, is mine as good as prize: sir Pandarus be my speed, ye are most fitly met sir.

sp.speaker: Mercer.
sp.p:
And you as well encountered, what of this heir?
hath your books been propitious?

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Sir, 'tis done, she's come, she is in my house, make yourself apt for courtship, stroke up your stockings, lose not an inch of your legs goodness; I am sure ye wear socks.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: There your books fail ye sir, in truth I wear no socks.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: I would ye had sir, it were the sweeter grace for your legs; get on your gloves, are they perfumed?

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: A pretty wash I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: 'Twill serve: your offers must be full of bounty, velvets to furnish a gown, silks for petticoats and foreparts, shag for linings; forget not some pretty jewel to fasten, after some little compliment: if she deny this courtesy, double your bounties, be not wanting in abundance, fullness of gifts, linked with a pleasing tongue, will win an anchorite. Sir, ye are my friend, and friend to all that professes good letters; I must not use this office else, it fits not for a scholar, and a gentleman: those stockings are of Naples, they are silk?

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Ye are again beside your text; sir, they are a the best of wool, and they cleped jersey.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Sure they are very dear?

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Nine shillings, by my love to learning.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Pardon my judgement, we scholars use no other objects, but their books.

sp.speaker: Mercer.
sp.p: There is one thing entombed in that grave breast, that makes me equally admire it with your scholarship.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Sir, but that in modesty I am bound not to affect mine own commendation, I would inquire it of you?

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Sure you are very honest, and yet ye have a kind of modest fear to show it: do not deny it, that face of yours, is a worthy learned modest face.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Sir, I can blush.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Virtue and grace are always paired together: but I will leave to stir your blood sir, and now to our business.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Forget not my instructions.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: I apprehend ye sir, I will gather myself together, with my best phrases, and so I shall discourse in some sort takingly.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: This was well worded sir, and like a scholar.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: The muses favour me as my intents are virtuous; sir ye shall be my tutor, 'tis never too late sir to love learning: when I can once speak true latin â€”

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: What do you intend sir?

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Marry I will then beggar all your bawdy writers, and undertake at the peril of my own invention, all pageants, poesies for chimneys, speeches for the Duke's entertainment, whensoever and whatsoever; nay I will build at mine own charge, an hospital, to which shall retire, all diseased opinions, all broken poets, all prose-men that are fallen from small sense, to mere letters; and it shall be lawful, for a lawyer, if he be a civil man, though a have undone others and himself by the language; to retire to this poor life, and learn to be honest.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Sir ye are very good, and very charitable: ye are a true pattern for the city sir.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Sir, I do know sufficiently their shop-books cannot save them, there is a further end â€”

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: O: sir much may be done by manuscript.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: I do confess it sir, provided still they be canonical, and have some worthy hands set to 'em for probation: but we forget ourselves.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Sir enter when you please, and all good language tip your tongue.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: All that love learning pray for my good success.

div.head: Actus iiii scaena iii.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Boy, whereabouts are we?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Sir by all tokens this is the house, bawdy I am sure by the broken windows, the fish head is within, if ye dare
venture, here you may surprise it.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: The misery of man may fitly be compared to a didapper, who when she is under water passed our sight, and indeed can seem no more to us, rises again, shakes but herself, and is the same she was; so is it still with transitory man, this day: o but an hour since, and I was mighty, mighty in knowledge, mighty in my hopes, mighty in blessed means, and was so truly happy, that I durst a said, live Lazarello, and be satisfied: but now â€”

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir ye are yet a float and may recover, be not your own wrack, here lies the harbour, go in and ride at ease.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Boy I am received to be a gentleman, a courtier, and a man of action, modest, and wise, and be it spoken with thy reverence child, abounding virtuous; and wouldst thou have a man of these choice habits, covet the cover of a bawdy house? yet if I go not in, I am but â€”

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But what sir?

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Dust boy, but dust, and my soul unsatisfied shall haunt the keepers of my blessed saint, and I will appear.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: An ass to all men; sir these are no means, to stay your appetite, you must resolve to enter.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Were not the house subject to martial law â€”

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: If that be all, sir ye may enter, for ye can know nothing here, that the court is ignorant of, only the more eyes shall look upon ye, for there they wink one at another's faults.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: If I do not,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then ye must beat fairly back again, fall to your physical mess of porridge, and the twice sacked carcase of a capon, fortune may favour you so much, to send the bread to it: but it's a mere venture, and money may be put out upon it.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: I will go in and live; pretend some love to the gentlewoman, screw myself in affection, and so be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: This fly is caught, is mashed already, I will suck him, and lay him by.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Muffle yourself in your cloak by any means, 'tis a received thing among gallants, to walk to their lechery, as though they had the rheum, 'twas well you brought not your horse.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Why boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Faith sir 'tis the fashion of our gentry, to have their horses wait at door like men, while the beasts their masters, are within at rack and manger, 'twould have discovered much.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: I will lay by these habits, forms, and grave respects of what I am, and be myself; only my appetite, my fire, my soul, my being, my dear appetite shall go along with me, armed with whose strength, I fear les will attempt the greatest danger dare oppose my fury: I am resolved wherever that thou art, most sacred dish, hid from unhollowed eyes, to find thee out.
sp.l: Be'st thou in hell, rapt by Proserpina,
To be a rival in black Pluto's love:
Or moves thou in the heavens, a form divine:
Lashing the lazy spheres:
Or if thou beest returned to thy first being,
Thy mother sea, there will I seek thee forth,
Earth, air, nor fire,
Nor the black shades below, shall bar my sight,
So daring is my powerful appetite.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, you may save this long voyage, and take a shorter cut, you have forgotten yourself, the fish head's here, your own imaginations have made you mad.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Term it a jealous fury good my boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Faith sir term it what you will, you must use other terms ere you can get it.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: The looks of my sweet love are fair, fresh and feeding as the air.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, you forget yourself.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Was never seen so rare a head, of any fish alive or dead.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Good sir remember, this is the house sir.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Cursed be he that dare not venture.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Pity yourself sir, and leave this fury.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: For such a prize, and so I enter.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Dun's ith' mire, get out again how a can: my honest gallant, I'll show you one trick more than ere the fool your father dreamt of yet. Madona Julia?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: What news my sweet rogue, my dear sin's broker, what? good news?

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: There is a kind of ignorant thing, much like a courtier, now gone in.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Is a gallant?

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: 'A shines not very gloriously, nor does 'a wear one skin perfumed to keep the tother sweet; his coat is not in or, nor does the world run yet on wheels with him; is rich enough, and has a small thing follows him, like to a boat tied to a tall ships tail: give him entertainment, be light and flashing like a meteor, hug him about the neck, give him a kiss, and lisping cry, good sir; and is thine own, as fast as 'a were tied to thine arms, by indentures.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I dare do more than this, if 'a be a the true court cut; I'll take him out a lesson worth the learning: but we are but their apes; what's he worth?

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Be he rich, or poor, if he will take thee with him, thou mayst use thy trade free from constables, and marshals: who hath been here since I went out?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: There is a gentlewoman sent hither by a lord, she's a piece of dainty stuff my rogue, smooth, and soft, as new satin; she was never gummed yet boy, nor fretted.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Where lies she?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: She lies above, towards the street, not to be spoke with, but by the lord that sent her, or some from him, we have in charge from his servants.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Peace, 'a comes out again upon discovery; up with all your canvas, hale him in; and when thou hast done, clap him a board bravely, my valiant pinnace.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Be gone, I shall do reason with him.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Are you the special beauty of this house?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sir, you have given it a more special regard by your good language, than these black brows can merit.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Lady you are fair.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Fair sir? I thank ye; all the poor means I have left to be thought grateful, is but a kiss, and ye shall have it sir.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Ye have a very moving lip.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Prove it again sir, it may be your sense was set too high, and so over wrought itself.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: 'Tis still the same: how far may ye hold the time to be spent lady?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Four o'clock sir.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I have not eat today.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You will have the better stomach to your supper; in the mean time, I'll feed ye with delight.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: 'Tis not so good upon an empty stomach: if it might be without the trouble of your house, I would eat?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sir, we can have a capon ready.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: The day?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Tis Friday sir.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I do eat little flesh upon these days.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Come sweet, ye shall not think on meat; I'll drown it with a better appetite.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I feel it work more strangely, I must eat.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Tis now too late to send; I say ye shall not think on meat: if ye do, by this kiss I'll be angry.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I could be far more sprightful, had I eaten, and more lasting.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What will ye have sir? name but the fish, my maid shall bring it, if it may be got.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: methinks your house should not be so unfurnished, as not to have some pretty modicum?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: It is so now: but could ye stay till supper?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Sure I have offended highly and much, and my inflictions make it manifest, I will retire henceforth, and keep my chamber, live privately, and die forgotten.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sir I must crave your pardon, I had forgotten myself; I have a dish of meat within, and it is fish, I think this dukedom holds not a daintier: 'tis an Umbrano's head.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Lady, this kiss is yours, and this.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Ho? within there? cover the board, and set the fish head on it.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Now am I so truly happy, so much above all fate and fortune, that I should despise that man, durst say, remember Lazarello, thou art mortal.

sp.speaker: 2. Intelligencer
sp.p: This is the villain, lay hands on him.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Gentlemen, why am I thus entreated? what is the nature of my crime?

sp.speaker: 2. Intelligencer
sp.p: Sir, though you have carried it a great while privately, and (As you think) well; yet we have seen your sir, and we do know thee Lazarello, for a traitor.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: The gods defend our Duke.

sp.speaker: 2. Intelligencer
sp.p: Amen. Sir, sir, this cannot save that stiff neck from the halter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I am glad you have discovered him, 'a should not have eaten under my roof for twenty pounds; and surely I did not like him, when a called for fish.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: My friends, will ye let me have that little favour â€”

sp.speaker: 1. Intelligencer
sp.p: Sir, ye shall have law, and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: To let me stay the eating of a bit or two, for I protest I am yet fasting?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I'll have no traitor come within my house.

sp.speaker: Lazar.
sp.p: Now could I wish myself, I had been traitor, I have strength enough for to endure it, had I but patience: man thou art but grass, thou art a bubble, and thou must perish.
sp.l: Then lead along, I am prepared for all.
Since I have lost my hopes, welcome my fall.

sp.speaker: 2. Intelligencer
sp.p: Away sir.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: As thou hast hope of man, stay but this dish this two hours, I doubt not but I shall be discharged: by this light I will marry thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You shall marry me first then?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I do contract myself unto thee now, before these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I'll preserve it till you be hanged, or quit.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Thanks, thanks.

sp.speaker: 2. Intelligencer
sp.p: Away, away, you shall thank her at the gallows.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Adieu, adieu.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If he live, I'll have him; if he be hanged, there's no loss in it.

div.stage: Enter Oriana and her waiting woman: look out at a window.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Hast thou provided one to bear my letter to my brother?

sp.speaker: Waiter
sp.p: I have enquired, but they of the house will suffer no letter nor message to be carried from you, but such as the lord Gondarino shall be acquainted with: truly madam, I suspect the house to be no better than it should be.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: What dost thou doubt?

sp.speaker: Waiter
sp.p: Faith, I am loath to tell it madam.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Out with it, 'tis not true modesty to fear to speak that thou dost think.

sp.speaker: Waiter
sp.p: I think it be one of these same bawdy houses.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter wench, we are warm in it; keep thou thy mind pure, and upon my word, that name will do thee no hurt: I cannot force myself yet to fear any thing; when I do get out, I'll have another encounter with my woman hater. Here will I sit, I may get sight of some of my friends, it must needs be a comfort to them to see me here.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Are we all sufficiently disguised? for this house where she attends me, is not to be visited in our own shapes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We are not ourselves.

sp.speaker: Arri.
sp.p: I know the house to be sinful enough, yet I have been heretofore, and durst now, but for discovering of you, appear here in my own likeness.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Where's Lucio?

sp.speaker: Arri.
sp.p: My lord, he said, the affairs of the commonwealth, would not suffer him to attend always.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Some great ones questionless that he will handle.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Come, let us enter?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: See how fortune strives, to revenge my quarrel upon these women, she's in the window, were it not to undo her, I should not look upon her.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Lead us. Gondarino.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Stay, since you force me to display my shame,
Look there, and you my lord, know you that face?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: 'Tis she?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: 'Tis she, whose greatest virtue ever was
Dissimulation, she that still hath striven
More to sin cunningly then to avoid it:
She that hath ever sought to be accounted
Most virtuous, when she did deserve most scandal:
'Tis she that itches now, and in the height
Of her intemperate thoughts, with greedy eyes
Expects my coming to allay her lust:
Leave her, forget she's thy sister.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Stay, stay.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am as full of this, as thou canst be,
The memory of this will easily
Hereafter stay my loose and wand'ring thoughts
From any woman.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: This will not down with me, I dare not trust this fellow.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Leave her here, that only shall be her punishment, never to be fetched from hence; but let her use her trade to get her living.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Stay, good my lord, I do believe all this, as great men as I have had known whores to their sisters, and have laughed at it, I would fain hear how she talks, since she grew thus light: will your grace make him show himself to her, as if he were now come to satisfy her longing? whilst we unseen of her, overhear her wantonness, let's make our best of it now we shall have good mirth.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Do it Gondarino.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I must; fortune assist me but this once.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Here we shall stand unseen, and near enough.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Madam, Oriana.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Who's that? O! my lord?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Shall I come up?

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: O you are merry, shall I come down?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: It is better there.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.p: What is the confession of the lie you made to the Duke, which I scarce believe yet you had impudence enough to do? did not gain you so much faith with me, as that I was willing to be at your lo. bestowing, till you had recovered my credit, and confessed yourself a liar, as you pretended to do? I confess I began to fear you, and desired to be out of your house, but your own followers forced me hither.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: 'Tis well suspected, dissemble still, for there are some may hear us.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.p: More tricks yet, my lord? what house this is I know not, I only know myself, it were a great conquest if you could fasten a scandal upon me: i'faith my lord, give me leave to write to my brother?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Come down.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Come down.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: If it please your grace there's a back door.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Come meet us there then?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: It seems you are acquainted with the house.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: I have been in it.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: She saw you, and dissembled.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Sir, we shall know that better.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Bring me unto her, if I prove her not
To be a strumpet, let me be contemned
Of all her sex.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Now whilst the young Duke follows his delights,
We that do mean to practise in the state,
Must pick our times, and set our faces in,
And nod our heads, as it may prove most fit
For the main good of the dear commonwealth:
Who's within there?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: My lord?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Secretary, fetch the gown I use to read petitions in, and the standish I answer French letters with, and call in the gentleman that attends:Exit Seru.
sp.l: Little know they that do not deal in state,
How many things there are to be observed,
Which seem but little; yet by one of us
(Whose brains do wind about the commonwealth)
Neglected, cracks our credits utterly. Enter gentleman and a servants.
Sir, but that I do presume upon your secrecy,
sp.p: I would not have appeared to you thus ignorantly attired without a toothpick in a ribbon, or a ring in my bandstrings.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Your lordship sent for me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I did: sir your long practice in the state under a great man hath led you to much experience.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Suffer not your modesty to excuse it, in short and in private I desire your direction, I take my study already to be furnished after a grave and wise method.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: What will this lord do?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: My book-strings are suitable and of a reaching colour.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: My standish of wood strange and sweet, and my fore-flap hangs in the right place, and as near Machiavel's, as can be gathered by tradition.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Are there such men as will say nothing abroad. and play the fools in their lodgings? this lord must be followed: and hath your lordship some new made words to scatter in your speeches in public, to gain note, that the hearers may carry them away, and dispute of them at dinner?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have sir: and besides my several gowns and caps agreeable to my several occasions.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis well, and you have learned to write a bad hand, that the readers may take pains for it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes sir: and I give out I have the palsy.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Good, 'twere better though, if you had it, your lo. hath a secretary, that can write fair, when you purpose to be understood.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Faith sir I have one, there he stands, he hath been my secretary this 7. years, but he hath forgotten to write.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: If he can make a writing face, it is not amiss, so he keep his own counsel: your lo. hath no hope of the gout?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Uh, little sir, since the pain in my right foot left me.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: 'Twill be some scandal to your wisdom, though I see your lo. knows enough in public business.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am not employed (Though to my desert) in occasion foreign, nor frequented for matters domestical.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Not frequented? what course takes your lordship?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The readiest way, my door stands wide, my secretary knows I am not denied to any.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: In this (Give me leave) your lordship is out of the way: make a back door to let out intelligencers; seem to be ever busy, and put your door under keepers, and you shall have a troop of clients sweating to come at you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have a backdoor already, I will henceforth be busy, secretary run and keep the door.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: This will fetch am?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Secr.
sp.p: My lord, there are some require access to you about weighty affairs of state.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: All ready.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I told you so.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: How weighty is the business.

sp.speaker: Secr.
sp.p: Treason my lord.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Sir, my debts to you for this are great.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I will leave your lordship now.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Sir my death must be sudden, if I requite you not; at the back door good sir.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: I will be your lordship's intelligencer for once.

sp.speaker: Secr.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Let 'em in, and say I am at my study.

div.stage: Enter Lazarello, and two intelligensers. Lucio being at his study.

sp.speaker: 1. In.
sp.p: Where is your lord?

sp.speaker: Secr.
sp.p: At his study, but he will have you brought in.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Why gentlemen, what will you charge me withal?

sp.speaker: 2. In.
sp.p: Treason, horrible treason, I hope to have the leading of thee to prison, and prick thee on ith' arse with a halbert: to have him hanged that salutes thee, and call all those in question, that spit not upon thee.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: My thread is spun, yet might I but call for this dish of meat at the gallous, in stead of a psalm, it were to be endured: the curtain opens, now my end draws on.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Gentlemen I am not empty of weighty occasions at this time; I pray you your business.

sp.speaker: 1. In.
sp.p: My lord, I think we have discovered one of the most bloody traitors, that ever the world held.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Signior Lazarillo, I am glad you're one of this discovery, give me your hand.

sp.speaker: 2. In.
sp.p: My lord that is the traitor.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Keep him off, I would not for my whole estate have touched him.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p:
Peace sir, I know the devil is at your tongue's end, to furnish you with speeches? what are the particulars?
you charge him with. They deliver a paper to Lucio, who reads.

sp.speaker: Both In.
sp.p: We have conferred our notes, and have extracted that, which we will justify upon our oaths.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: That he would be greater than the Duke, that he had cast plots for this, and meant to corrupt some to betray him, that he would burn the city, kill the Duke, and poison the privy council; and lastly kill himself. Though thou deservest justly to be hanged, with silence yet I allow thee to speak, be short.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: My lord, so many my greatest wish succeed,
So may I live, and compass what I seek,
As I had never treason in my thoughts,
Nor ever did conspire the overthrow
Of any creatures, but of brutish beasts,
Fowls, fishes, and such other human food
As is provided for the good of man,
If stealing custards, tarts, and Florentines
By some late statute be created treason;
How many fellow courtiers can I bring,
Whose long attendance, and experience,
Hath made them deeper in the plot than I.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Peace, such hath ever been the clemency of my gracious master the Duke, in all his proceedings, that I had thought, and thought I had thought rightly; that malice would long ere this, have hid herself in her den, and have turned her own sting against her own heart: but I well now perceive; that so forward is the disposition of a depraved nature; that it doth not only seek revenge, where it hath received injuries; but many times thirst after their destruction, where it hath met with benefits.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: But my good lord â€”

sp.speaker: 2. In.
sp.p: Let's gag him.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Peace again, but many times thirst after destruction, where it hath met with benefits; there I left: such, and no better are the business, that we have now in hand.

sp.speaker: 1. In.
sp.p: He's excellently spoken.

sp.speaker: 2. In.
sp.p: He'll wind a traitor I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: But surely methinks , setting aside the touch of conscience, and all other inward convulsions.

sp.speaker: 2. In.
sp.p: He'll be hanged, I know by that word.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Your lordship may consider â€”

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Hold thy peace: thou canst not answer this speech: no traitor can answer it: but because you cannot answer this speech; I take it you have confessed the treason.

sp.speaker: 1. In.
sp.p: The count valour was the first that discovered him, and can witness it, but he left the matter to your lordship's grave consideration.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: I thank his lordship, carry him away speedily to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: Now Lazarillo thou are tumbled down
The hill of fortune, with a violent arm;
All plagues that can be, famine, and the sword
Will light upon thee, black despair will boil
In thy dispairing breast, no comfort by,
Thy friends far off, thy enemies are nigh.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Away with him, I'll follow you, look you pinion him, and take his money from hurt, lest he swallow a shilling and kill himself.

sp.speaker: 2. In.
sp.p: Get then on before.

div.head: Actus 5. Scaena. 3.
div.stage: Enter the Duke, the count, Gondarino, and Arrigo.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now Gondarino, what can you put on now
That may again deceive us,
Have ye more strange illusions, yet more mists,
Through which the weak eye may be led to error:
What can ye say that may do satisfaction
Both for her wronged honour, and your ill?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: All I can say or may is said already,
She is unchaste, or else I have no knowledge,
I do not breathe, nor have the use of sense.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Dare ye be yet so wilful, ignorant,
Of your own nakedness, did not your servants
In mine own hearing confess
They brought her to that house, we found her in;
Almost by force: and with a great distrust
Of some ensuing hazard.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: He that hath begun so worthily,
It fits not with his resolution
To leave of thus: my lord I know these are but idle proves.
What says your lordship to them?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Count, I dare yet pronounce again, thy sister is not honest.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: You are yourself my lord, I like your settledness.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Count thou art young, and unexperienced, in the dark hidden ways of women. Thou dar'st affirm with confidence a lady of fifteen may be a maid.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Sir if it were not so, I have a sister would set near my heart.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Let her sit near her shame, it better fits her: call back the blood that made our stream in nearness, and turn the currant to a better use, 'tis too much mudded, I do grieve to know it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Darest thou make up again, dar'st to turn face, knowing we know thee, hast thou not been discovered openly: did not our ears hear her deny thy courtings? did we not see her blush with modest anger, to be so overtaken by a trick; can ye deny this lord?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Had not your grace, and her kind brother
Been within level of her eye,
You should have had a hotter volley from her
More full of blood and fire, ready to leap the window, where she stood.
So truly sensual is her appetite,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Sir, sir, these are but words and tricks, give me the proof.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What need a better proof than your lordship, I am sure ye have lain with her my lord.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I have confessed it sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I dare not give thee credit without witness.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Does your grace think, we carry seconds, with us, to search us, and see fair play: your grace hath been ill tutored in the business; but if you hope to try her truly, and satisfy yourself what frailty is, give he the test: do not remember count she is your sister; nor let my lord the Duke believe she is fair; but put her to't without hope or pity, than ye shall see that golden form fly off, that all eyes wonder at for pure and fixed, and under it, base blushing copper; mettle not worth the meanest honour: you shall behold her then my lord transparent, look through her heart, and view the spirits how they leap, and tell me then, I did belie the lady.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It shall be done: come Gondarino bear us company,
We do believe thee she shall die, and thou shalt see it.
How now my friends, whom have ye guarded hither.

sp.speaker: 2. In.
sp.p: So please your grace we have discovered a a villain and a traitor: the lord Lucio hath examined him, and sent him to your grace for judgement.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My lord, I dare absolve him from all sin of treason: I know his most ambitions is but a dish of meat; which a' hath hunted, with so true a sent, that he deserveth the collar, not the halter.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why do they bring him thus bound up? the poor man had more need of some warm meat, to comfort his cold stomach.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Your grace shall have the cause hereafter, when when you may laugh more freely. But these are called informers: men that live by treason; as rat-chatchers do by poison.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Could there were no heavier prodigies hung over us, than this poor fellow, I durst redeem all perils ready to pour themselves upon this state, with a cold custard.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Your grace might do it, without danger toy our person.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: My lord, if ever I intended treason against your person, or the state, unless it were by wishing from your table, some dish of meat; which I must needs confess, was not a subject's part: or coveting by stealth, sups from those noble bottles, that no mouth keeping allegiance true, should dare to taste: I must confess with more than covetous eyes, I have be held those dear concealed dishes, that have been brought in, by cunning equipage, to wait upon your grace's palate: I do confess out of this present heat, I have had stratagems, and ambuscadoes: but God be thanked they have never took.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Count, this business is your own; when you have done, repair to us.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: I will attend your grace: Lazarello, you are at liberty, be your own man again; and if ye can be master of your wishes, I wish it may be so.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I humbly thank your lordship: I must be unmannerly, I have some present business, once more I heartily thank your lordship.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Now even a word or two to you, and so farewell; you think you have deserved much of this state, by this discovery: you're a slavish people, grown subject to the common course of all men. How much unhappy were that noble spirit, could work by such baser gains? what misery would not a knowing man put on, with willingness, ere he see himself grown fat and full fed, by fall of those you rise by? I do discharge ye my attendance; our healthful state needs no such leeches to suck out her blood.

sp.speaker: 1 Intel.
sp.p: I do beseech your lordship.

sp.speaker: 2 intelligencer
sp.p: Good my l.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Go learn to be more honest, when I see you work your means from honest industry,Exeunt informers.
I will be willing to accept your labours:
Till then I will keep back my promised favours:
Here comes another remnant of folly:Enter Lucio.
sp.p: I must dispatch him too. Now lord Lucio, what business bring you hither?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: Faith sir, I am discovering what will become of that notable piece of treason, intended by that varlet Lazarello; I have sent him to the Duke for judgement.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir you have performed the part of a most careful statesman, and let me say it to your face, sir of a father to this state: I would wish you to retire, and ensconce yourself in study: for such is your daily labour, and our fear, that the loss of an hour may breed our overthrow.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: Sir I will be commanded by your judgement, and though I find it a trouble scant to be waded through, by these weak years, yet for the dear care of the commonwealth, I will bruise my brains, and confine myself to much vexation.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Go, and mayest thou knock down treason like an ox.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Have I spoke thus much in the honour of learning? learned the names of the seven liberal sciences, before my marriage; and since, have in haste written epistles congratulary, to the 9 muses: and is she proved a whore and a beggar?

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: 'Tis true, you are not now to be taught, that no man can be learned of a sudden; let not your first project discourage you, what you have lost in this, you may get again in alchemy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Fear not husband, I hope to make as good a wife, as the best of your neighbours have, and as honest.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: I will go home; good sir do not publish this, as long as it runs among ourselves; 'tis good honest mirth: you'll come home to supper; I mean to have all her friends and mine as ill as it goes.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Do wisely sir, and bid your own friends, your whole wealth will scarce feast all hers, neither is it for your cedit, to walk the streets, with a woman so noted, get you home, and provide her clothes: let her come an hour hence with an hand-basket and shift herself, she'll serve to sit at the upper end of the table, and drink to your customers.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Art is just, and will make me amends.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: No doubt sir.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: The chief note of a scholar you say, is to govern his passions; wherefore I do take all patiently; in sign of which my most dear wife, I do kiss thee: make haste home after me, I shall be in my study.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Go, a vaunt, my new city dame, send me what you promised me for consideration; and mayest thou prove a lady.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Thou shalt have it, his silks shall fly for it.

sp.speaker: Lazarello.
sp.p: How sweet is a calm after a tempest, what is there now that can stand betwixt me and felicity? I have gone through all my crosses constantly; have confounded my enemies, and know where to have my longings satisfied; I have my way before me, there is the door, and I may freely walk into my delights. knock boy.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Who's their?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Madonna my love, not guilty, not guilty, open the door.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Art thou come sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Yes to thy soft embraces, and the rest of my overflowing blisses; come let us in and swim in our delights: a short grace as we go, and so to meat.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Nay my dear love, you must bear with me in this; we'll to the church first.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.p: Shall I be sure of it then.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: By my love you shall.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I am content, for I do now wish to hold off longer, to whet my appetite, and do desire to meet with more troubles, so I might conquer them.
sp.l: And as a holy lover that hath spent
The tedious night, with many a sigh and tears;
Whilst he pursued his wench: and hath observed
The smiles, and frowns, not daring to displease;
When at last, hath with his service won
Her yielding heart; that she begins to dote
upon him, and can hold not longer out,
But hangs about his neck, and woes him more
Than ever he desired her love before:
Then begins to flatter his desert,
And growing wanton, needs will cast her off;
Try her, pick quarrels, to breed fresh delight,
And to increase his pleasing appetite.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Come mouse, will you walk?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I pray thee let me be delivered of the joy I am so big with; I do feel that high heat within me, that I begin to doubt whether I be mortal?
sp.l: How I contemn my fellows in the court,
With whom I did but yesterday converse,
And in a lower and an humbler key
Did walk, and meditate on grosser meats:
There are they still poor rogues, shaking their chops,
And sneaking after cheeses, and do run
Headlong in chase of every jack of beer
That crosseth them, in hope of some repast,
That it will bring them to; whilst I am here,
The happiest wight, that ever set his tooth
To a dear novelty: approach my love,
Come let's go to knit the true love's knot,
That never can be broken.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That is to marry a whore.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: When that is done, then will we taste the gift,
Which fates have sent, my fortunes up to lift.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: When that is done, you'll begin to repent, upon a full stomach; but I see, 'tis but a form in destiny, not to be altered.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Sir, what may be the currant of your business, that thus you single out your time and place?

sp.speaker: Arrigo.
sp.p: Madam, the business now imposed upon me, concerns you nearly; I wish some worser man might finish it.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Why are ye changed so? are ye not well sir?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Yes madam, I am well, would you were so.

sp.speaker: Orrian.
sp.p: Why sir? I feel myself in perfect health.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: And yet ye cannot live long, madam.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Why good Arrigo?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Why, ye must die.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: I know I must, but yet my fate calls not upon me.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: It does; this hand the Duke commands shall give you death.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Heaven, and the powers divine, guard well the innocent.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Lady, your prayers may do your soul some good,
That sure your body cannot merit by 'em:
You must prepare to die.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.l: What's my offence? what have these years committed,
That may be dangerous to the Duke or state?
Have I conspired by poison? have I given up
My honour to some loose unsettled blood
That may give action to my plots?
Dear sir, let me not die ignorant of my faults?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Ye shall not.
Then lady, you must know, you are held unhonest;
The Duke, your brother, and your friends in court,
With too much grief condemn ye: though to me,
The fault deserves not to be paid with death.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Who is my accuser?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Lord Gondarino.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.l: Arrigo, take these words, and bear them to the Duke,
It is the last petition I shall ask thee:
Tell him the child, this present hour brought forth
To see the world, has not a soul more pure, more white,
More virgin than I have. Tell him lord Gondarino's
Plot, I suffer for, and willingly: tell him it had been a greater
Honour, to have saved then killed: but I have done: strike,
I am armed for heaven. Why stay you? is there any hope?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: I would not strike.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Have you the power to save?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: With hazard of my life, if it should be known?

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: You will not venture that?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: I will: lady, there is that means yet to escape your death, if you can wisely apprehend it.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Ye dare not be so kind?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: I dare, and will, if you dare but deserve it.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: If I should slight my life, I were too blame.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Then madam, this is the means, or else you die: I love you.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: I shall believe it, if you save my life.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: And you must lie with me.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: I dare not buy my life so.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Come ye must resolve, say yea or no.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.l: Then no; nay look not ruggedly upon me,
I am made up too strong, to fear such looks.
Come, do your butcher's part: before I would win life,
With the dear loss of honour, I dare find means to free myself.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Speak, will ye yield?

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Villain, I will not; murderer do thy worst, thy base unnoble thoughts dare prompt thee to; I am above thee slave.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Will thou not be drawn to yield by fair persuasions?

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: No nor by â€”

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Peace, know your doom then; your ladyship must remember, you are not now at home, where you dare jest at all that come about you: but you are fallen under my mercy, which shall be small: if thou refuse to yield, hear what I have sworn unto myself; I will enjoy thee, though it between the parting of thy soul and body. Yield yet and live.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: I'll guard the one, let heavens guard the tother.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Are ye so resolute then? Duke. from above. Hold, hold, I say.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: What have I? yet more terror to my tragedy?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Lady, the scene of blood is done; ye are now as free from scandal, as from death.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou woman which wert born to teach virtue
Fair, sweet, and modest maid forgive my thoughts,
My trespass was my love. Seize Gondarino, let him ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ dooms.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I do begin in a little to love this woman; I could endure her already twelve miles off.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sister, I am glad you have brought your honour off so fairly, without loss: you have done a work above your sex, the Duke admires it; give him fair encounter.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Best of all comforts; may I take this hand, and call it mine?

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: I am your grace's handmaid.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Would ye had said myself: might it not be so lady?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sister, say I: I know ye can afford it.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: My lord, I am your subject, you may command me, provided still, your thoughts be fair and good.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Here, I am yours; and when I cease to be so,
Let heaven forget me: thus I make it good.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.p: My lord, I am no more mine own.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: So: this bargain was well driven.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Duke, thou hast sold away thyself to all perdition; thou art this present hour becoming cuckold: methinks I see thy gall grate through thy veins, and jealousy seize thee with her talents: I know that woman's nose must be cut off, she cannot scape it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Sir, we have punishment for you.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: I do beseech your lordship, for the wrongs this man hath done me, let me pronounce his punishment.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Lady, I give to you, he is your own.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I do beseech your grace, let me be banished with all the speed that may be.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Stay still, you shall attend her sentence.

sp.speaker: Orian.
sp.p: Lord Gondarino, you have wronged me highly, yet since it sprung from no peculiar hate to me, but from a general dislike unto all women, you shall thus suffer for it; Arrigo, call in some ladies to assist us: will your grace take your state?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: My lord I do beseech your grace for any punishment saving this woman, let me be sent upon discovery of some island, I do desire but a small gondole, with ten holland cheeses, and I'll undertake it.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Sir ye must be content, will ye sit down? nay do it willingly. Arrigo tie his arms close to the chair, I dare not trust his patience.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Mayest thou be quickly old and painted; mayest thou dote upon some sturdy yeoman of the woodyard, and he be honest; mayest thou be barred the lawful lechery of thy coach for want of instruments; and last, be thy womb unopened.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This fellow hath a pretty gall.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My lord, I hope to see him purged ere a part.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Your ladyships are welcome: I must desire your helps, though you are no physicians, to do a strange cure upon this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: In what we can assist ye madam, ye may command us.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Now do I fit like a conjurer within my circle, and these the devils that are raised about me, I will pray that they may have no power upon me.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Ladies fall off in couples, then with a soft still march with low demeanours, charge this gentleman: I'll be your leader.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Let me be quartered Duke quickly, I can endure it: these women, long for man's flesh, let them have it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Count, have you ever seen so strange a passion? what would this fellow do, if a should find himself in bed with a young lady?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Faith my lord, if a could get a knife, sure a would cut her throat, or else 'a would do as Hercules did by Lycas, swing out her soul: has the true hate of a woman in him.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Low with your curtsies ladies.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p:
Come not too near me, I have a breath will poison ye, my lungs are rotten, and my stomach raw; I
am given much to belching: hold off, as you love sweet airs; ladies by your first night's pleasure, I conjure you, as you would have your husband's proper men, strong backs, and little legs, as you would have they hate your waiting women.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Sir we must court ye till we have obtained some little favour from those gracious eyes, 'tis but a kiss a piece.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I pronounce perdition to ye all; ye are a parcel of that damned crew, that fell down with Lucifer, and here ye stayed on earth, to plague poor men; vanish, avaunt, I am fortified against your charms; heaven grant me breath and patience.

sp.speaker: 1. Lady.
sp.p: Shall we not kiss then?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: No, fear my lips with hot irons first, or stitch them up like a ferret's: oh that this brunt were over.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: Come, come, little rogue, thou art too maidenly by my troth, I think I must box thee, till thou beest boulder; the more bold, the more welcome: I pray thee kiss me, be not afraid?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: If there be any here, that yet have so much of the fool left in them, as to love their mothers, let them look on her, and loathe them too.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: What a slovenly little villain art thou, why dost thou not stroke up thy hair? I think thou never combest it: I must have it lie in better order; so, so, so, let me see thy hands, are they washed?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I would they were loose for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: She tortures him admirably.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The best that ever was.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: Alas how cold they are poor golls, why dost thee not get thee a musse?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Madam, here's an old country gentlewoman at the door, that came nodding up for justice, she was with the lord Gondarino today, and would now again come? to the speech of him; she says.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Let her in, for sport's sake, let her in.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p:
Mercy oh Duke, I do appeal to thee: plant
cannons there, and discharge them against my breast rather: nay first, let this she fury sit still where she does, and with her nimble fingers stroke my hair, play with my finger's ends, or anything, until my panting heart have broken my breast.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You must abide her censure.

div.stage: The lady rises from his knee. Enter old gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: I see her come, unbutton me, for she will speak.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: Where is he sir?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Save me, I hear her.

sp.speaker: Arri.
sp.p: There he is in state, to give you audience.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: How does your good lordship?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Sick of the spleen.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Sick.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: Will you chew a nutmeg, you shall not refuse it, 'tis very comfortable.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Nay now thou art come, I know it is the devil's jubilee, hell is broke loose:
My lord, if ever I have done you service,
Or have deserved a favour of your grace,
Let me be turned upon some present action,
Where I may sooner die, then languish thus;
Your grace hath her petition, grant it her, and ease me now at last.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No sir, you must endure.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: For my petition; I hope your lordship hath remembered me.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: Faith I begin to pity him, Arrigo take her off, bear her away; say her petition is granted.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.p: Whether do you draw me sir? I know it is not my lord's pleasure I should be thus used, before my business be dispatched?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: You shall know more of that without.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p:
Unbind him ladies, but before he go, this he shall promise; for the love I bear to our own sex, I would have them still hated by thee, and enjoin thee as a punishment,
never hereafter willingly to come in the presence or fight of any woman, nor never to seek wrongfully the public disgrace of any.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: 'Tis that I would have sworn, and do: when I meddle with them, for their good, or their bad; may time call back this day again, and when I come in their companies, may I catch the pox, by their breath, and have no other pleasure for it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Ye are too merciful.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.p: My lord, I showed my sex the better.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: All is overblown sister, you're like to have a fair night of it, and a prince in your arms: let's go my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Thus through the doubtful streams of joy and true love doth wade, and finds at last relief.

div.p: (Virtue, teach men thoughts, him wait our

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
